[[France]] | coordinates = {{coord|48|50|19.15|N|2|22|42.60|E|region:FR-IDF|display=inline,title}} | type = | genre = | broke_ground = {{Start date|df=yes|1981|02}} | built = | opened = {{Start date|df=yes|1984|02|03}} | renovated = 2014–15 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Ville de Paris | operator = SEM Palais omnisports de Paris-Bercy | surface = Versatile | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = {{hlist|[[:fr:ANPAR|Andrault & Parat]]|[[:fr:Jean Prouvé|Jean Prouvé]]|Aydin Guvan}} | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | seating_type = | capacity = [[Concerts]]: 20,300
[[Boxing]]: 16,394
[[Tennis]]: 15,609
[[Handball]]: 15,609
[[Basketball]]: 15,609
[[Ice Hockey]]: 15,000
[[Sport of athletics|Athletics]]: 10,910 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | field_shape = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = | embedded = | website = {{URL|http://www.accorhotelsarena.com|accorhotelsarena.com}} | publictransit = }} '''AccorHotels Arena''' (originally known as '''Palais Omnisports de Paris-Bercy''' and formerly known as '''Bercy Arena''') is an indoor sports [[arena]] and [[concert hall]], that is located in the neighborhood of [[Bercy]], on boulevard de Bercy, in the [[12th arrondissement of Paris|12th arrondissement]] of [[Paris, France]]. The closest métro station is [[Bercy (Paris Métro)|Bercy]]. Designed by the architectural firm Andrault-Parat, [[Jean Prouvé]] and Aydin Guvan, the arena has a pyramidal shape, and walls covered with a sloping lawn. It has a [[seating capacity]] ranging from 7,000 to 20,300, depending on the event. ==History== [[File:AccorHotels Arena (Bercy Arena).jpg|thumb|left|The arena during the Paris Masters in 2008.]] It has been used as the main venue for the [[Paris Masters]] [[ATP Tour]] [[tennis]] tournament, and for many sports events, such as: [[table tennis]], [[team handball|handball]], [[basketball]], [[boxing]], [[artistic gymnastics|gymnastics]], [[track cycling]], [[show jumping]], and more. POPB hosted the European gymnastics championship in 2000, the [[1991 EuroLeague Final Four|1991]] and [[1996 EuroLeague Final Four|1996]][http://217.13.116.51/finalfour05/noticia.jsp?temporada=E02&jornada=20&id=379 1996 Final Four: Victory comes to Greece and the Greens] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012144543/http://217.13.116.51/finalfour05/noticia.jsp?temporada=E02&jornada=20&id=379 |date=12 October 2007 }} [[EuroLeague|FIBA EuroLeague]] [[EuroLeague Final Four|Final Four]]s, and the [[FIBA EuroBasket]] championship in [[EuroBasket 1999|1999]], among others. It also hosted the [[2009–10 Euroleague|2009–10]] [[EuroLeague]] [[2010 EuroLeague Final Four|Final Four]]. It also hosted the [[Masters Karting Paris Bercy]] star race, from 1993 to 2001, and again in 2011. It is also serving as a host, along with [[Lanxess Arena]] in [[Cologne, Germany]] of the [[2017 IIHF World Championship]]. On 28 June, it was announced that the arena would host the 2017 [[League of Legends Championship Series#Europe|European League of Legends Championship Series]] Summer Finals.{{Cite news|url=https://www.lequipe.fr/Esport/Actualites/Esport-league-of-legends-les-finales-lcs-a-l-accorhotels-arena-de-paris/814150|title=eSport - League of Legends : les finales LCS à l'AccorHotels Arena de Paris|last=Arrivé|first=Paul|date=28 June 2017|work=L'Équipe|access-date=2017-06-28|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=fr-FR}} As part of the 2014–15 renovations efforts, the arena was renamed to Bercy Arena on 1 January 2015. It was again renamed to AccorHotels Arena in October 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.hotelnewsresource.com/article86000.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-10-12 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160509034238/http://www.hotelnewsresource.com/article86000.html |archivedate=2016-05-09 |df= }} The arena will host the 2019 [[League of Legends World Championship]] Finals. AccorHotels Arena will be a venue for [[2024 Summer Olympics]]. ===Ticket sales=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |+ World's Busiest Arenas – 2016{{Cite news|url=http://www.pollstarpro.com/files/Charts2016/2016YearEndWorldwideTicketSalesTop200ArenaVenues.pdf|title=TOP 200 ARENA VENUES 2016|last=|first=|date=31 December 2016|work=|access-date=}} |- ! Jason Pielak | music = Brahm Wenger | studio = [[Robert Vince|Keystone Family Pictures]] | distributor = [[Walt Disney Studios Home Entertainment|Walt Disney Home Entertainment]] | released = June 18, 2002 | runtime = 93 minutes | country = United States | language = English }} '''''Air Bud: Seventh Inning Fetch''''' (also known as '''''Air Bud 4''''') is a 2002 Direct-To-Video American film, and the fourth film in the ''[[Air Bud]]'' series. ==Plot== Josh is off to his first year of college and Buddy has stayed behind with Josh's little sister, Andrea, and the rest of the family. Jackie and Patrick have recently welcomed Josh and Andrea's half brother Noah. Andrea, attempting to fit in with her junior high classmates, decides to join the baseball team. Along the way she discovers that Buddy also has the uncanny ability to play baseball. Just as the season is settling in, a terrible discovery is made—Buddy's puppies have mysteriously started disappearing with the help of the kidnappers' little helper, Rocky Raccoon. It turns out the kidnappers were researchers who were dognapping the puppies because they thought they had a special gene that would enable them to play sports. Buddy must find them and make it to the major leagues as he goes to bat for the [[Anaheim Angels]]. ==Cast== *[[Kevin Zegers]] - Josh Framm *[[Caitlin Wachs]] - Andrea Framm *[[Cynthia Stevenson]] - Jackie Framm Sullivan *[[Richard Karn]] - Dr. Patrick Sullivan *[[Molly Hagan]] - Coach Crenshaw *[[Shayn Solberg]] - Tom Stewart *[[Hannah Marof]] and [[Emma Marof]] - Noah Sullivan *[[Chantal Strand]] - Tammy *[[Frank C. Turner]] - Carlton *[[Doug Funk]] - Mailman Phil / Announcer *[[Jim Hughson]]- Announcer *[[Patrick Cranshaw]] - Sheriff Bob *[[Ellen Kennedy]] - Wilma, Tammy's Mother *[[Jeremy Mersereau]] - Dog-Hating Fan (uncredited) *[[Shooter]] as Buddy *[[Jordy Cunningham]] - World Series Pitcher (uncredited) *[[Todd Allan]] - World Series Catcher/Right Fielder (uncredited) ==External links== *{{Official Website|http://buddies.disney.com/air-bud-seventh-inning-fetch}} * {{IMDb title|0288415}} * {{Amg title|261094}} {{The Air Bud Series}} {{Robert Vince}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Air Bud Seventh Inning Fetch}} [[Category:2002 films]] [[Category:2002 direct-to-video films]] [[Category:2000s sports films]] [[Category:Direct-to-video sequel films]] [[Category:Disney direct-to-video films]] [[Category:Films about dogs]] [[Category:Films about animals playing sports]] [[Category:American baseball films]] [[Category:Films directed by Robert Vince]] [[Category:Air Bud (series)]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films shot in Vancouver]] [[Category:American sequel films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:DHX Media films]] [[Category:Films about animals]] [[Category:American children's films]] {{child-film-stub}} {{sport-film-stub}}

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Eastern States Coliseum | nickname = The Big E Coliseum | image = | location = [[West Springfield, Massachusetts]] | coordinates = {{coord|42.091333| -72.618694|display=title}} | broke_ground = 1916 | opened = 1916 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[West Springfield, Massachusetts|City Of West Springfield]] | operator = [[The Big E|Eastern States Exposition]] | surface = dirt | architect = | capacity = 6,000 | tenants = [[Springfield Indians]] ([[Canadian-American Hockey League|CAHL]]/[[American Hockey League|AHL]]) (1926–1932, 1935–1972)
[[New England Whalers]] ([[World Hockey Association|WHA]]) (1974–1975)
[[Massachusetts Twisters]] ([[American Indoor Soccer League|AISL]]/[[National Indoor Soccer League|NISL]]) (2002–2009) | construction_cost = | former_names = | website = [http://www.thebige.com/p/agriculture/coliseum/ Official Website] |}} The '''Eastern States Coliseum''', better known as the '''Big E Coliseum''', is a 5,900-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[West Springfield, Massachusetts]]. ==History== The Big E Coliseum was built in 1916. The longtime home of the [[Springfield Indians]] professional hockey team in the [[American Hockey League]], it was a part-time home to the [[New England Whalers]] [[ice hockey]] team while the team was in the [[World Hockey Association]].{{cite news |last=Brown |first=Garry |date=May 9, 2009 |title=Hartford Whalers, now Carolina Hurricanes, found their way to Springfield Civic Center, Eastern States Coliseum |url=http://www.masslive.com/sports/index.ssf/2009/05/hartford_whalers_now_carolina.html |newspaper=Springfield Union-News |location= |publisher=Larry McDermott |accessdate=18 August 2014 }} In the 1940s through to the building of the [[Springfield Civic Center]] in 1972, the Coliseum frequently hosted local showings of the [[Ice Capades]] and the [[Ice Follies]].{{cite news |last= |first= |date=November 1, 1959 |title=Birthday Edition Of Ice Capades Hailed By Critics |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courant/access/914255212.html?dids=914255212:914255212&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Nov+01%2C+1959&author=&pub=Hartford+Courant&desc=Birthday+Edition+Of+Ice+Capades+Hailed+By+Critics&pqatl=google |newspaper=Hartford Courant |location=Hartford, Connecticut |publisher= |accessdate=18 August 2014 }} It was for many years the largest capacity rink in western Massachusetts, and was the home arena of several local high school hockey teams as well as a prominent venue for regional and state high school tournaments.{{cite news |last=Porter |first=Matt |date=March 13, 2008 |title=Cheers fade, but glory endures |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-15504316.html |newspaper=Boston Globe |location= |publisher= |accessdate=18 August 2014 }} Today, though the ice plant has been dismantled and hockey games are no longer played there,{{cite news |last=Donahue |first=Chris |date=April 1, 1991 |title=Hockey mecca's demise leaves high schools scrambling |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/USAToday/access/56142294.html?dids=56142294:56142294&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Apr+01%2C+1991&author=Chris+Donahue&pub=USA+TODAY+%28pre-1997+Fulltext%29&desc=HIGH+SCHOOL+NOTES%3BMass.+hockey+mecca%27s+demise+leaves+schools+scrambling&pqatl=google |newspaper=USA Today |location=|accessdate=18 August 2014 }} the arena is a venue for [[The Big E]], and hosts Shriner circuses, equestrian shows and other local events.[http://www.thebige.com/ Eastern States Exhibition website] The Coliseum has often been the location for the draft horse World Championship Finals, serving as such in 1998, 1999, 2002, 2003, 2004 and 2009,{{cite web |url=http://www.thebige.com/fair/horseshow/horseshow.asp |title=BigE Draft Horse Show |author= |date= |website=The Big E |publisher=Eastern States Exhibition |accessdate=18 August 2014}} and has been a venue for rodeos.{{cite news |last=Blowen |first=Michael |date=March 27, 1993 |title=Rodeo king |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-8220696.html |newspaper=Boston Globe |location= |publisher=William Taylor |accessdate=18 August 2014 }} ==Indians and The Coliseum== The first game played in the new arena was on December 1, 1926. Boxing promoter [[Tex Rickard]] dropped the ceremonial first puck. The [[Springfield Indians]] lost to the [[Providence Reds]] 3–1. In 1933, the parent [[New York Rangers]] decided to pull the franchise out of Springfield, but the Indians were back in the Coliseum for the 1935–36 season when [[J. Lucien Garneau]] transferred his [[Quebec City]] club to Springfield. When World War II broke out, the franchise had to be suspended for the duration of the war due to the [[Eastern States Exposition]] grounds being commandeered by the [[United States Army]] for use as a quartermaster's depot. The Indians were back at the Coliseum for the 1946–47 season until 1972, when the team moved into the [[Springfield Civic Center]] in downtown Springfield at the start of the 1972–73 season. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[New England Whalers]] | years = 1973 – 1975 | before = [[Boston Arena]] | after = [[Hartford Civic Center]] }} {{end}} {{Hartford Whalers}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Big E Coliseum}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Springfield Indians]] [[Category:Defunct National Hockey League venues]] [[Category:World Hockey Association venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Springfield, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Rodeo venues in the United States]] [[Category:Defunct indoor soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:1916 establishments in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1916]]

{{distinguish|Centennial Park Stadium}} {{refimprove|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox stadium |stadium_name = Centennial Stadium |nickname = |image = File:Centennial Stadium Victoria.jpg |location = [[University of Victoria]] |broke_ground = 1966 |opened = 1967 |owner = University of Victoria |operator = University of Victoria |surface = Natural Grass
Rubberized 400m track |construction_cost = $512,084 |architect = Sidall, Dennis and Associates |tenants = [[Victoria Vikes]] ([[U Sports]])
[[Victoria Highlanders]] ([[USL League Two|USL L2]]) (2016–present) |seating_capacity = 5,000 }} '''Centennial Stadium''' is a stadium located on the campus of the [[University of Victoria]] in [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]], [[British Columbia]], Canada. The facility was built as a 1967 Canadian Centennial project to celebrate the [[Canadian Centennial|100th anniversary of Canadian confederation]].The Emergence of Architectural Modernism in Victoria - http://uvac.uvic.ca/Architecture_Exhibits/UVic_campus/buildings/Centennial_Stadium/ The original seating capacity was 3,000. The venue was renovated and temporarily expanded to 30,000 seats to serve as the main stadium of the [[1994 Commonwealth Games]]. After the Commonwealth Games, the temporary seats were removed, leaving 2,000 new seats opposite the main grandstand for a total of 5,000 seats. The stadium features a 400m synthetic rubberized track surface, as well as separate areas for [[long jump]]/[[triple jump]], [[high jump]], [[pole vault]], [[Discus throw|discus]], [[Hammer throw|hammer]], [[shot put]], and [[Javelin throw|javelin]]. Inside the track is a natural grass field for sports such as [[Canadian football|football]] and [[soccer]]. Centennial Stadium is the home of the [[Victoria Vikes]] soccer team of [[Canadian Interuniversity Sport]]. It was also used as a soccer venue for the [[2002 FIFA U-19 Women's World Championship]]. == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://maps.google.com/?ie=UTF8&ll=48.467508,-123.315074&spn=0.002515,0.004989&t=k&z=18&om=1 Satellite view of Centennial Stadium on Google Maps] {{Commonwealth Games stadia}} {{Premier Development League stadiums}} {{coord|48.467478|N|123.315031|W|display=title}} [[Category:Sports venues in Victoria, British Columbia]] [[Category:1994 Commonwealth Games venues]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in Canada]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Canada]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Canada]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Canada]] [[Category:Canadian Centennial]] [[Category:1967 establishments in British Columbia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1967]] {{BritishColumbia-struct-stub}} {{Canada-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | name = City Stadium | image = | location = [[Molodechno]], [[Belarus]] | coordinates = {{Coord|53|1|17|N|27|32|46|E|display=inline|type:landmark}} | built = | opened = 1946 | renovated = 2004–2005 | closed = | demolished = | owner = | surface = Grass | former_names = | tenants = [[FC Molodechno-DYuSSh-4|Molodechno-DYuSSh-4]]
[[FC SKVICH Minsk|Lokomotiv Minsk]] (2006–2008)
[[FC Isloch Minsk Raion|Isloch Minsk Raion]] (2015–) | capacity = 4,800 }} '''City Stadium''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Molodechno]], [[Belarus]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and is the home ground of [[FC Molodechno-DYuSSh-4|Molodechno-DYuSSh-4]]. The stadium holds 4,800 spectators. ==History== The stadium was opened in 1946 and has been used by a local club [[FC Molodechno]] ever since. It was known as '''Metallurg Stadium''' until 1993, before being renamed to '''City Stadium'''. Between 2006 and 2008 it was a home venue for [[FC SKVICH Minsk|Lokomotiv Minsk]] and in 2015 it was used by [[FC Isloch Minsk Raion|Isloch Minsk Raion]].[http://by.tribuna.com/tribuna/blogs/navulicymajoj/916521.html Molodechno Stadium returns to Premier League] ==International use== Over the years Molodechno City Stadium has been used as an occasional home venue for [[Belarus national under-21 football team|Belarus national under-21 team]] and [[Belarus women's national football team|Belarus women's national team]]. It has hosted some games of UEFA youth (U17/19) championships qualifying groups. In 1996, it the stadium hosted a [[friendly match]] of [[Belarus national football team|Belarus national team]] against [[Azerbaijan national football team|Azerbaijan]]. In mid-90s it was also used as a home venue for [[FC Dinamo-93 Minsk|Dinamo-93 Minsk]] in European Cups. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.pressball.by/footballstat/stadiums/29/ Stadium profile at pressball.by] [[Category:Football venues in Belarus]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Minsk Region]] {{Belarus-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox basketball biography | name = Drilon Hajrizi | image = | number = 17 | position = [[Stretch four|Forward]] | height_ft = 6 | height_in = 8 | weight_lb = 238 | league = B.League | team = Kanazawa Samuraiz | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1991|1|17|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Mitrovica, Kosovo|Mitrovica]], [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|SFR Yugoslavia]] | nationality = Kosovan | high_school = | college = | draft_year = 2013 | career_start = | years1 = {{0|0000}}–2013 | team1 = [[KB Trepça|Trepça]] | years2 = 2013–2016 | team2 = [[KB Peja|Peja]] | years3 = 2016–2017 | team3 = [[Sigal Prishtina]] | years4 = 2018– | team4 = [[Kanazawa Samuraiz]] }} '''Drilon Hajrizi''' (born 17 January 1991) is a [[Kosovo Albanian]] professional [[basketball]] player and he is currently playing professionally with the [[Kanazawa Samuraiz]] of the [[B.League]].
==Professional career== <!---------------------------------- ===Trepça=== {{Empty section|date=February 2018}} ===Peja=== {{Empty section|date=February 2018}} ===Sigal Prishtina=== {{Empty section|date=February 2018}} -----------------------------------> ===Kanazawa Samuraiz=== On 3 January 2018. Hajrizi joined to [[B.League]] side [[Kanazawa Samuraiz]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://borozani.com/artikulli/drilon-hajrizi-transferohet-ne-japoni/fbk|title=Drilon Hajrizi transferohet në Japoni|language=Albanian|website=Borozani|date=3 January 2018}}</ref> On 17 January 2018, Kanazawa Samuraiz announced the transfer of Hajrizi via a status on their official [[Facebook]] account.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lajmi.net/zyrtare-drilon-hajrizi-ne-japoni/|title=ZYRTARE: Drilon Hajrizi në Japoni|language=Albanian|website=Lajmi.net|date=17 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurobasket.com/Kosovo/news/519612/Drilon-Hajrizi-presented-at-Japanese-team|title=Drilon Hajrizi presented at Japanese team|website=Eurobasket|date=17 January 2018}}</ref>
==International career== Hajrizi was one of the first players of [[Kosovo national basketball team|Kosovo]]. On 31 August 2016, he making his official debut with Kosovo in a [[EuroBasket 2017 qualification#Group E|EuroBasket 2017 qualification]] match against [[Slovenia national basketball team|Slovenia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurobasket.com/boxScores/European%20Championships/2016/0831_SLO_KOS.asp|title=Slovenia (113–68) Kosovo|website=Eurobasket|date=31 August 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://basketball.asia-basket.com/player/Drilon_Hajrizi/Japan/Kanazawa-Samuraiz/176448 Drilon Hajrizi] at eurobasket.com

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2015}} {{fanpov|date=December 2014}} {{infobox person |name = Ed Anzalone |image = Fireman Ed 1-21-10.JPG |alt = |caption = Ed at a Jets Championship Rally of the 2009 playoffs 1–21–10 in [[Times Square]]. |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1959|9|19}} |birth_place = [[College Point, NY]] |death_place = |nationality = |other_names = |known_for = |occupation = New York City Firefighter }} '''Edwin M. Anzalone''' (born September 19, 1959),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/travel/news/story?id=4774588|title=Pilgrimage: A farewell to Giants|first=Kristian|last=Dyer|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=December 27, 2009|accessdate=December 28, 2009}}</ref> better known as '''Fireman Ed''', is a superfan of the [[New York Jets]].<ref>{{Citation|last=Pressman|first=Stacey|title=To date, or not to date|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/print?id=1541856&type=page2Story|publisher=[[ESPN.com]]|date=April 21, 2003|accessdate=September 19, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Lange|first=Randy|title=Stadium Stories: New York Jets|publisher=Globe Pequot Press|year=2005|isbn=0-7627-3783-2}}</ref> One of the most well known [[National Football League]] fans, he has risen to prominence by appearing on many local radio shows.<ref>{{cite news|last=Greenberg|first=Jay|title=PLAYOFFS STARTIN' TO ADD UP|url=https://secure.nypost.com/seven/10232006/sports/jets/playoffs_startin_to_add_up_jets_jay_greenberg.htm|date=October 23, 2006|accessdate=September 27, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Berger|first=Ken|title=Martin, secondary spark the Jets|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=1905742|publisher=[[ESPN.com]]|date=October 21, 2004|accessdate=September 19, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Soshnick|first=Scott|title=U.S. Pro Sports Fans Don't Know What a Fan Is|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=10000039&sid=a5f7hE82YrEk&refer=columnist_soshnick|publisher=Bloomberg|date=March 23, 2006|accessdate=September 19, 2007}}</ref> He was ''not'' the creator of the famous chant, "J-E-T-S, Jets!, Jets!, Jets!" <ref>{{cite news|last=Murphy|first=Brian|title=Here's to you, New York|url=http://espn.go.com/page2/s/murphy/010917.html|publisher=[[ESPN.com]]|accessdate=September 19, 2007}}</ref> which originally was led by two retired NYPD Jet fans – alternating from one end zone to the other end zone, in the upper deck only.<ref>{{cite web|title=Where did the JETS chant come from?|url=http://www.jetkingdom.com/information/faq/jets_chant|accessdate=September 25, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Bromberg|first=Greg|title=Most Fierce NFL Mascot Competition: Fireman Ed vs. T.D.|url=http://www.sportsline.com/spin/story/10851162|publisher=[[CBS Sports]]|date=|accessdate=June 28, 2008}}</ref> An actual [[New York City Fire Department|New York City firefighter]], Fireman Ed was injured on the job in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.firemaned.net/about.html|title=About Us|publisher=Firemaned.net|accessdate=August 14, 2012}}</ref> During the [[butt fumble]] game, a rout of the Jets by the New England Patriots on Thanksgiving night 2012, Anzalone left the game before halftime, stating that he would no longer lead cheers at Jet games as Fireman Ed.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hanzus|first=Dan|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap1000000100909/article/fireman-ed-no-longer-new-york-jets-mascot|work=[[National Football League]]|date=November 26, 2012|title=Fireman Ed quits as New York Jets' unofficial mascot|deadurl=no|accessdate=December 11, 2012}}</ref> At the first game of the 2015 NFL season, Fireman Ed returned to lead cheers for the Jets.<ref name=edreturns>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/new-york-jets/post/_/id/54089/fireman-ed-back-for-new-york-jets-home-opener|title=Fireman Ed returns for Jets' opener, to the delight of Brandon Marshall, Darrelle Revis|last=Darcy|first=Kieran|work=[[ESPN.com]]|date=September 14, 2015|accessdate=September 14, 2015}}</ref>
==Fandom== Anzalone wears [[Bruce Harper]]'s jersey to games,<ref>{{cite news|last=Baumbach|first=Jim|title=Where are they now: Jets returner Bruce Harper|url=http://www.newsday.com/sports/football/where-are-they-now-jets-returner-bruce-harper-1.877749|publisher=''[[Newsday]]''|date=December 15, 2007|accessdate=December 2, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Waszak|first=Dennis|title=Jets give Fireman Ed game ball from win over Pats|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news?slug=ap-jets-firemaned&prov=ap&type=lgns|publisher=[[Yahoo! Sports]]|date=September 25, 2009|accessdate=September 27, 2009}}</ref> however he switched to [[Mark Sanchez]]'s jersey for the [[2012 NFL season]] in support of the quarterback, and has been leading the J-E-T-S chant from Section 134 of the [[Giants Stadium|Meadowlands]] since 1986. He used to be hoisted up on the shoulders of his brother Frank, then later onto those of Bruce Gregor after Frank developed knee problems.<ref>{{cite news|title=Die-hard New York Jets supporter Bruce 'The Base' Gregor is the man the beneath J-E-T-S chant|first=Ian|last=Powers|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/football/jets/2010/01/24/2010-01-24_meet_the_man_beneath_the_jets_chant.html|publisher=''[[New York Daily News]]''|date=January 24, 2010|accessdate=January 24, 2010}}</ref> In 1999, Fireman Ed was included in an exhibit at the [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]] as part of the Hall of Fans.<ref>{{cite news|last=Florence|first=Mal|title=You Have to Be Fan of Absurdity to Make This Hall|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1999/jan/22/sports/sp-677|publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''|date=January 22, 1999|accessdate=January 1, 2009}}</ref>
On September 25, 2009, Fireman Ed was given a game ball from the Jets Week 2 victory over the [[New England Patriots]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Associated Press|title=Jets give Fireman Ed game ball|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=4503739|publisher=[[ESPN.com]]|date=September 25, 2009|accessdate=September 25, 2009}}</ref> On December 30, 2009, [[Cincinnati Bengals]] wide receiver [[Chad Johnson (wide receiver)|Chad Johnson]] claimed he would imitate Fireman Ed if he scores a touchdown in his next game against the Jets, on January 3, 2010.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ochocinco promises new routine|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=4782365|publisher=ESPN.com|date=December 31, 2009|accessdate=January 3, 2010}}</ref> The day after the Bengals' loss in Week 17, Johnson got in contact with Fireman Ed through Twitter and provided him with a VIP package for the Jets first round playoff game at [[Cincinnati Bengals|Cincinnati]], as a way to make up for the "trash-talking" that occurred before the game. Though he was appreciative of the offer he declined, on the moral ground that he did not think it was right to be flown out to the game by the opposing team. He did however say that if the Jets made him an offer he would take them up on it, though no offer was made.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/OGOchoCinco|title=Ocho Cinco (@OGOchoCinco) op Twitter|publisher=Twitter.com|date=|accessdate=August 14, 2012}}</ref>
On November 22, 2012, during a [[Thanksgiving]] night Jets blowout 49–19 loss to the [[New England Patriots]], Ed left the game at halftime and deleted his Twitter account.<ref>[http://espn.go.com/blog/new-york/jets/post/_/id/18107/notes-where-art-ed Notes:Where art Ed?] ''Jane McManus, ESPN'' Retrieved November 23, 2012.</ref> He "retired" as the self-proclaimed mascot of the NY Jets, stating he will attend games but not in character.
On September 13, 2015, Fireman Ed returned in character at the Jets' home opener against the [[Cleveland Browns]].
==Controversy== On August 16, 2010, during a [[Monday Night Football]] Giants vs. Jets pre-season game, Fireman Ed's inaugural Jets chant in the [[New Meadowlands Stadium]] was interrupted by a [[New York Giants|Giants]] fan who raised his Giants hat while Fireman Ed's fellow Jets fans stood by. Fireman Ed repeatedly shoved the fan before the fan was escorted away from Ed's chanting post.<ref>{{cite news|title=New York Jets Superfan, Fireman Ed Shows His Angry Side|first=Paula|last=Duffy|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/paula-duffy/new-york-jets-superfan-fi_b_685621.html|publisher=''[[The Huffington Post]]''|date=August 17, 2010|accessdate=August 23, 2010}}</ref> The Giants fan was later removed from the game. Fireman Ed was charged with simple assault for the incident,<ref>{{cite web|title=Fireman Ed Charged with Assault of Giants Fan|first=Andy|last=Benoit|url=http://nfl-facts-and-rumors.blogs.cbssports.com/mcc/blogs/entry/22475988/24764698|publisher=cbssports|date=September 22, 2010|accessdate=September 23, 2010}}</ref> but the charges were later dropped.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jets fan Fireman Ed cleared of assault as Giants fan Christopher Black drops charges|first=Larry|last=McShane|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2010/10/28/2010-10-28_jets_fan_fireman_ed_cleared_of_assault_as_giants_fan_christopher_black_drops_cha.html|newspaper=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|location=New York|date=October 28, 2010|accessdate=October 30, 2010}}</ref>
==Personal life== Anzalone has been a resident of [[East Rutherford, New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nj.com/jets/index.ssf/2010/09/jets_fan_fireman_ed_anzalone_c.html|title=Jets fan 'Fireman Ed' Anzalone could face assault charge in wake of incident involving Giants fan|publisher=[[The Star-Ledger]]|author=Conor Orr|date=September 23, 2010|deadurl=no|accessdate=December 11, 2012|quote=Anzalone, a 51-year-old retired New York City firefighter now residing in East Rutherford, serves as an unofficial figurehead in the Jets fan section.}}</ref>
==See also== * [[The 7 Line Army]] * [[Barrel Man (Denver Broncos)|Barrel Man]] * [[Bleacher Creatures]] * [[Chief Zee]] * [[Crazy Ray]] * [[Hogettes]] * [[License Plate Guy]] * [[Pinto Ron]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{commons category}} * [http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2011/01/12/fireman-ed-on-wfan-i-can-handle-new-england-crowd/ Fireman Ed Radio interview]
{{New York Jets}}

revision.text:
{{infobox | headerstyle = background-color: white | title = GEM Altigliss Challenge | image = | label3 = '''Association Established''' | data3 = 1986 | label4 = First Edition | data4 = 2004 | label5 = '''Sponsors:''' | data5 = [[KPMG]]
[[Club des Sports de Val d'Isère]]
[[Grenoble École de Management]]
[[Val d'Isere]]
[[Groupe Casino]] | label6 = '''Location''' | data6 = [[Val d'Isère]] {{Location map | France | width = 200 | lat_deg = 45.4506 | lon_deg = 6.9781 | label = Val d'Isère}}}} '''GEM Altigliss Challenge''' is the biggest [[skiing|ski]] and [[snowboarding|snowboard]] student event in Europe. The week-long event is organized annually in March by Altigliss, a student association of [[Grenoble School of Management|Grenoble École de Management]]. It is classified by the newspaper Le Point Etudiants[http://www.lepointetudiants.net/lemag/ Le Point Etudiants (2013)], [http://www.lepointetudiants.net/lemag/?p=4940 GEM Altigliss Challenge], Retrieved 27 November 2013 as the third biggest event organized by a student association in 2013. GEM Altigliss Challenge is the biggest ski and snowboard student event in Europe. The week-long event is organized annually in March by Altigliss, a student association of Grenoble École de Management. The challenge unites an average of a 1000 university students combining more than 25 nationalities, from 30 [[Grandes écoles]] and other European universities.Mélodie Moulin, 7 March 2013, [http://www.studyramagrandesecoles.com/home.php?Id=8134 Dans les coulisses, une grande organisation], Retrieved 27 November 2013 The challenge is held at [[Val-d’Isère]], ski resort in the [[Rhône-Alpes]] [[Regions of France|region]] of [[France]]. == History == This challenge had originally begun in 2004 under the name of Altigliss Challenge. In 2011, the name was officially changed to GEM Altigliss Challenge following to increasing popularity of the event. The first official edition of GEM Altigliss Challenge took place in February 2012.http://www.mcetv.fr (21 March 2013),[http://mcetv.fr/news-express/2511-gem-altigliss-challenge-un-nouveau-nom-porte-bonheur-pour-la-13eme-edition GEM Altigliss Challenge : Un nouveau nom porte bonheur pour la 13ème édition…], Retrieved 28 November 2013 == Challenges == The traditional challenges of the GEM Altigliss Challenge are the Ski Challenge, The Mountain Challenge and the Village Challenge.http://www.altigliss.com (2013), [http://www.altigliss.com/challenges Le Ski Challenge], Retrieved 27 November 2013 ===Ski Challenge=== The Ski Challenge consists in five different events listed below:Morgane, F., 17 August 2012, [http://www.skiinfo.fr/actualites/a/561579/gem-altigliss-challenge-à-val-d-isère GEM ALTIGLISS CHALLENGE à Val d'Isère], Retrieved 27 November 2013http://www.mcetv.fr (21 March 2013),[http://mcetv.fr/mon-mag-campus/2103-gem-altigliss-challenge-partenaire-de-ma-chaine-etudiante Gem Altigliss Challenge partenaire de Ma Chaîne étudiante], Retrieved 27 November 2013 [[File:Wilmot-ski-racer-cmsc.jpg|thumb|Giant Slalom Ski Racer]] *Le Slalom Géant ([[Giant slalom]]) is the opening event of the GEM Altigliss challenge. Participants must slide down a winding track through poles as quickly as possible to win the first round. *Le Boarder Cross involves four teams competing against each other on a timed rocky obstacle course. *Le Big Air is an event where participants jump on a trampoline to perform intricate tricks to impress a panel of judges. *Le Slalom Spécial is the most technical event of the Ski Challenge. It differs from Le Slalom Geant with narrower gates and a shorter course. *Le Slalom Parallèle is a team challenge composed of a qualifying and a final round. Four best teams in the overall running compete to score the most points. ===Mountain Challenge=== The Mountain Challenge is a recent addition to the GEM Altigliss. The winner receives prizes from the event’s sponsors. The mountain challenge is made up of the following four events:Morgane, F., 17 August 2012, [http://www.skiinfo.fr/actualites/a/561579/gem-altigliss-challenge-à-val-d-isère GEM ALTIGLISS CHALLENGE à Val d'Isère], Retrieved 27 November 2013 *Course D’Orientation (Orienteering Course). The participants have to find tags which are distributed around [[Espace Killy]] with a given map of the resort and a compass. *Chasse au Trésor (Treasure Hunt). Participants solve various puzzles scattered around the corners of the ski area to find a grand prize. *"From A to B" is a team race. Every team starts off at Point A and the goal is to make it to Point B first. Any kind of transport is allowed. This includes skis, snowboard, telemark, car, bus, motorcycle, snowshoes and anything else participants can think of. *Derby is a team race where each team must descend down a chosen track in record time. The winning team is the one whose last member arriving has the shortest time of descent. ===Village Challenge=== The Village Challenge is the entertainment program of the GEM Altigliss Challenge. This includes:Morgane, F., 17 August 2012, [http://www.skiinfo.fr/actualites/a/561579/gem-altigliss-challenge-à-val-d-isère GEM ALTIGLISS CHALLENGE à Val d'Isère], Retrieved 27 November 2013 *Indoor and outdoor activities (games, [[sledding]], [[toboggan]]ing) *Parties at the local nightclubs, Le Graal and La Doudoune *Best-dressed contest ==Ride Her First == Ride Her First is a [[freestyle skiing]] contest which takes place during the GEM Altigliss Challenge. During the competition professional freeskiers and snowboarders perform tricks on a specially prepared obstacle course. The event is usually combined with a [[Disc jockey|DJ]] performance and it is graded 2 stars in the [[Ticket to Ride (World Snowboard Tour)]].[http://www.lepointetudiants.net/lemag/ Le Point Etudiants (2013)], [http://www.lepointetudiants.net/lemag/?p=4332 Altigliss Association], Retrieved 27 November 2013 === Event format === The finals of Ride Her First are divided into two parts. The first official part is a team contest in which riders perform tricks on the course, in groups of three. The teams are judged by style, technique and synchronization of the tricks. The best groups are rewarded with prizes in skiing and snowboarding equipment. The second part of the finals is the free session, during which competitors are rewarded with a cash prize. The amount of money received by a rider depends on the reaction of the crowd to his performance. However, the contest itself is open only to professionals. Amateurs can only take part in the qualifications, but not the finals, which take place the day before the main competition. Amateurs can win a 'wild card' which enables them to enter the main contest.http://www.altigliss.com (2013), [http://www.altigliss.com/ride-her-first Ride Her First 2013: Un Contest Mais Pas Que!], Retrieved 27 November 2013 ==== Obstacles and course aspect ==== The course for Ride Her First is divided into the Jump and the Rail sections. The challenge takes place at Val Park [[Snowpark|Terrain park]]. The event course usually features a jump from the top of the slope followed by rails at the bottom.http://www.altigliss.com (2013), [http://www.altigliss.com/ride-her-first Ride Her First], Retrieved 27 November 2013 ==Disabled Sports== [[File:Dd0394- Lillehammer Winter Games, R.Hacon - 3b- scanned photo.jpg|thumb|left]] In the GEM Altigliss Challenge, one day (Thursday, March 29, 2014) is dedicated to the disabled participants.Stéphane Lagoutiere (2013), [http://www.france-handicap-info.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1511%3A14e-edition-gem-altigliss-challenge-sensibilisation-des-etudiants-au-handicap-au-val-disere&catid=46%3Amanifestation-sportive&Itemid=60&lang=fr 14E Edition GEM Altigliss Challenge : Sensibilisation Des Étudiants Au Handicap Au Val d'Isère], Retrieved 27 November 2013 The reason for the [[Disabled sports]] day, is due to the history of [[Alpine skiing]]. Alpine skiing was one of the first sports made available for disabled athletes. Therefore, ski resorts have adapted to the growing demand of having disabled-accessible infrastructures and possibilities in their areas. During the GEM Altigliss Challenge, athletes have the opportunity to test dual ski and stabilo, and are able to train for [[Para-alpine skiing]], organized by professional ski instructors.Mélodie Moulin, 7 March 2013, [http://www.studyramagrandesecoles.com/home.php?Id=8134 Des journées à thème], Retrieved 27 November 2013 ==Location== [[File:Espace Killy.jpg|thumb|framed|right|Espace Killy]] GEM Altigliss Challenge is held annually in the ski destination of Val d’Isère. The event lasts one complete week. It is located 166 km from [[Grenoble]], home of Grenoble École de Management and the Altigliss association; the university ski and snowboard world cup remains accessible to many students of the area. Val d’Isère provides the setting for a week of competition, offering a range of slopes and panorama for participants and the public experience. The resort is situated 240 km from [[Lyon]] and 220 km from [[Geneva]], as well as 5 km from the Franco-Italian border. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.altigliss.com/ Official website of the GEM Altigliss Challenge] [[Category:Skiing in France]] [[Category:Student sport]]

{{refimprove|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox Sport governing body | assocname = Ghana Karate Do Association | abbrev = (GKF) | logo = | sport = [[Karate]] | category = | image = | caption = | jurisdiction = National | founded = 30 April 1997 | aff = [[World Karate Federation]] (WKF) | affdate = | region = [[Union of African Karate Federation]] | regionyear = | headquarters = | location = | president = | chairman = | board = | chair = | chiefexec = | secretary = | coach = | womenscoach = | operating income = | sponsor = | year closed = | replaced = | prevfounded = | url = | countryflag = Ghana | countryflag2 = | countryflag3 = }}
'''Ghana Karate Do Association''' it is the largest association for karate in Ghana and a member as well as the official representative for this sport in the [[Ghana Olympic Committee]]. It was founded in 1997.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.modernghana.com/news/503186/tribute-from-ghana-karate-do-association-to-mr-jude-adu-ama.html|title=Tribute From Ghana Karate-Do Association To Mr Jude Adu- Amankwah, Former President Of Ghana Karate Association|first=Peter|last=Agbeko|publisher=|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref>
==History==
Karate was first introduced in Ghana in the second half of the 1990s. Until the late 1990s, karate training in Ghana was more of a traditional martial art than a sport. Karate prospered because of the immense contribution of practitioners and mentors such as Sensei Daniel Djura, founder of Africa Goju; Sensei Donald Djura; Sensei Moses Baiden; Sensei Duke Banson; and Sensei Quagrine.
On 30 April 1997, a national body was registered and inaugurated with the National Sports Council (NSC) in the name of Ghana Karate-Do Federation (GKF) as the 26th sporting association.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=0rnTWd17UngC&pg=PA8&lpg=PA8&dq=GHANA+KARATE+DO+ASSOCIATION&source=bl&ots=vOWwLMutS0&sig=wTi-y7uwcbzAGfrSBYIRAedMVWg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjK4pzH8pTYAhXRp6QKHYXlCIw4ChDoAQgoMAA#v=onepage&q=GHANA+KARATE+DO+ASSOCIATION&f=false|title=Graphic Sports: Issue 624 May 6-12 1997|first=Joe|last=Aggrey|date=6 May 1997|publisher=Graphic Communications Group|accessdate=19 December 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref> The GKF was affiliated to the [[Union of African Karate Federation]] (UFAK) and eventually to the [[World Karate Federation]] (WKF).
The founding members were Melvin Brown, Francis Fuster, Benjamin Selormey, Victor Amara, Daniel Gyamfi and Samuel Akpalu. After the inauguration of the federation, there was the need to form an executive and a technical committee. The executive committee was chaired by Rtd. Captain George Mould, and FrancisFuster and Jude Adu-Amankwah were his vice.{{clarification needed|date=February 2018|reason=vice what?}} All the other members were karatekas and served on the technical committee with Benjamin Selormey as Technical Director.
The Ghana Karate-Do Federation later came to be recognized as Ghana Karate-Do Association.
In 2004 Jude Adu-Amankwah took over from Capt. Mould as president of the association, with Sensei Melvin Brown as Technical Director, and Sensei Kwabena A. Poku as Referee and vice to the Technical Director. The other members of the technical committee were Sensei Prince Wilson, Sensei George-Slater Commodore, Sensei Saadisu Mamah Idrissu, Sensei Frank Danso Bekoe and Sensei Sylvester Davies. The technical committee is in charge of coaching and general training and grading of karatekas at the national level.
The membership of the executive committee was changed in 2009, with Michael Nunoo as the Chairman of the association and Sensei Saadisu Idrissu as the Technical Director. The present composition of the Management Board as of May 2011 is Michael Nunoo, Chairman; Ade Sawyer, Vice-Chairman; Patrick Anyidoho-Cofie, General Secretary; Nathaniel Nartey, member; Sensei Kwabena Poku, Head Coach; Sensei Frank Danso Bekoe, Deputy Coach; and Dr. Sulley, member. The executive committee is now referred to as the management board.
The present members of the technical committee are Sensei Kwabena A. Poku, Head Coach; Sensei Prince Wilson; Sensei Frank Danso Bekoe, Deputy Coach; Sensei Isaac Amponsah; Sensei Ibrahim Jarrah; Victor Lartey; and Emmanuel Adjei.
The GKA took its first outing the year it was inaugurated, in 1997, to the UFAK Zone 3 Championships in the Ivory Coast, and won two gold, four silver and two bronze medals. Since then the association has participated in many yearly UFAK Zone 3 Championships and has performed increasingly well, winning laurels in both Kumite and Kata. The Association has also represented Ghana in three All Africa Games since its inauguration: in 1997, 2003 and 2007, when contestant Victor Lartey won by correction of a previous decision.
==International competition==
Ghana Karate Do Association is a member of the African umbrella organization [[Union of African Karate Federation]] (UAKF) as well as the World Association for [[World Karate Federation]] (WKF).
On the part of the Ghana Olympic Committee, the Ghana Karate Association is the only Karate Association authorized to send athletes to the Olympic Games.

{{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Impingement syndrome | synonyms = Subacromial impingement, painful arc syndrome, supraspinatus syndrome, swimmer's shoulder, thrower's shoulder | image = | caption = | pronounce = | field = [[Orthopedics]], [[sports medicine]] | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }} '''Shoulder impingement syndrome''' is a [[syndrome]] which occurs when the [[Tendon|tendons]] of the [[rotator cuff]] muscles become irritated and inflamed as they pass through the [[subacromial space]], the passage beneath the [[acromion]]. This can result in pain, weakness and loss of movement at the [[shoulder]].<ref name="pmid9490991">{{cite journal |vauthors=Fongemie AE, Buss DD, Rolnick SJ |title=Management of shoulder impingement syndrome and rotator cuff tears |journal=Am Fam Physician |volume=57 |issue=4 |pages=667–74, 680–2 |date=February 1998 |pmid=9490991 |doi= |url=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=SimonMoyes.com |title= What is Subacromial Impingement? |url=http://simonmoyes.co.uk/2011/02/11/what-is-subacromial-impingement/}}</ref>
==Signs and symptoms== The most common symptoms in impingement syndrome are pain, weakness and a loss of movement at the affected shoulder.<ref name="pmid9490991" /> The pain is often worsened by shoulder overhead movement and may occur at night, especially when lying on the affected shoulder. The onset of the pain may be acute if due to an injury or insidious if due to a gradual process such as an [[Osteoarthritis|osteoarthritic]] [[Spur (zoology)|spur]]. The pain has been described as dull rather than sharp, and lingers for long periods of a time, making it hard to fall sleep.<ref name="pmid9490991" /> Other symptoms can include a grinding or popping sensation during movement of the shoulder.<ref name="chen03" />
The range of motion at the shoulder may be limited by pain. A painful arc of movement may be present during forward elevation of the arm from 60° to 120°.<ref name="chen03">{{cite journal |vauthors=Chen AL, Rokito AS, Zuckerman JD |title=The role of the acromioclavicular joint in impingement syndrome |journal=[[Clin Sports Med]] |volume=22 |issue=2 |pages=343–57 |date=April 2003 |pmid=12825535 |doi= 10.1016/S0278-5919(03)00015-2|url=}}</ref> Passive movement at the shoulder will appear painful when a downwards force is applied at the [[acromion]] but the pain will ease once the downwards force is removed.<ref name="pmid9490991" />
==Causes== When the arm is raised, the subacromial space (gap between the anterior edge of the acromion and the head of the [[humerus]]) narrows; the [[supraspinatus muscle]] tendon passes through this space.<ref>NEER, C. S. (1983). Impingement lesions. Clinical Orthopaedics and Related Research, 173, 70-77.</ref> Anything that causes further narrowing has the tendency to impinge the tendon and cause an inflammatory response, resulting in impingement syndrome. Such causes can be bony structures such as subacromial spurs (bony projections from the acromion), osteoarthritic spurs on the [[Acromioclavicular joint|acromioclavicular joint,]] and variations in the shape of the acromion. Thickening or calcification of the [[coracoacromial ligament]] can also cause impingement. Loss of function of the rotator cuff muscles, due to injury or loss of strength, may cause the humerus to move superiorly, resulting in impingement. Inflammation and subsequent thickening of the subacromial bursa may also cause impingement.<ref name="pmid9490991" />
Weight training exercises where the arms are elevated above shoulder height but in an internally rotated position such as the [[upright row]] have been suggested as a cause of subacromial impingement.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Schoenfeld |first1=Brad |last2=Kolber |first2=Morey J |last3=Haimes |first3=Jonathan E |title=The Upright Row: Implications for Preventing Subacromial Impingement |journal=Strength and Conditioning Journal |date=October 2011 |volume=33 |issue=5 |pages=25–28 |doi=10.1519/SSC.0b013e31822ec3e3 }}</ref> Another common cause of Impingement syndrome is restrictions in the range movement of the scapulo-thoracic surfaces. Commonly, a rib (or ribs) between rib 2 and rib 7/8 on the side of the impingement, may jut out slightly and/or feel hard when the person springs on it/them. When this occurs, the [[scapula]] is raised and anteverted (angled forwards). This in turn pushes the acromion and the humeral head out of its usual anatomical position placing pressure downwards at the head of the humerus at the position of the nerve thus causing the impingement syndrome. This is visibly demonstrated by a slightly raised and protracted shoulder girdle. Note: the humerus anteverts in this position causing a more protrusive section of the humerus to press upwards towards the acromion.
==Mechanism== The [[scapula]] plays an important role in shoulder impingement syndrome.<ref name="Kibler, BW. 1998">Kibler, BW. (1998). The role of the scapula in athletic shoulder function. The American Journal of Sports Medicine, 26(2), 325-337.</ref> It is a wide, flat bone lying on the posterior [[thoracic wall]] that provides an attachment for three different groups of muscles. The intrinsic muscles of the scapula include the muscles of the rotator cuff- the [[Subscapularis muscle|subscapularis]], [[Infraspinatus muscle|infraspinatus]], [[Teres minor muscle|teres minor]] and [[Supraspinatus muscle|supraspinatus]].<ref>Marieb, E. (2005). Anatomy & Physiology (2nd ed.). San Francisco, CA: Pearson Benjamin Cummings.</ref> These muscles attach to the surface of the scapula and are responsible for the internal and external rotation of the glenohumeral joint, along with humeral abduction. The extrinsic muscles include the [[biceps]], [[triceps]], and [[Deltoid muscle|deltoid]] muscles and attach to the coracoid process and supraglenoid tubercle of the scapula, infraglenoid tubercle of the scapula, and spine of the scapula. These muscles are responsible for several actions of the glenohumeral joint. The third group, which is mainly responsible for stabilization and rotation of the scapula, consists of the trapezius, serratus anterior, levator scapulae, and rhomboid muscles and attach to the medial, superior, and inferior borders of the scapula. Each of these muscles has their own role in shoulder function and must be in balance with each other in order to avoid shoulder pathology.
Abnormal scapular function is called scapular dyskinesis. One action the scapula performs during a throwing or serving motion is elevation of the acromion process in order to avoid impingement of the rotator cuff tendons.<ref name="Kibler, BW. 1998" /> If the scapula fails to properly elevate the acromion, impingement may occur during the cocking and acceleration phase of an overhead activity. The two muscles most commonly inhibited during this first part of an overhead motion are the serratus anterior and the lower trapezius.<ref name="Cools, A. 2007">Cools, A., Dewitte, V., Lanszweert, F., Notebaert, D., Roets, A., et al. (2007). Rehabilitation of scapular muscle balance. The American Journal of Sports Medicine, 35(10), 1744.</ref> These two muscles act as a force couple within the glenohumeral joint to properly elevate the acromion process, and if a muscle imbalance exists, shoulder impingement may develop.
==Diagnosis== [[File:MRI. Subacromial impingement..jpg|thumb|MRI showing subacromial impingement with partial rupture of the supraspinatus tendon. However, no retraction or fatty degeneration of the supraspinatus muscle.]] Impingement syndrome can usually be diagnosed by history and physical exam. On physical exam, the physician may twist or elevate the patient's arm to test for reproducible pain (the [[Neer Impingement Test|Neer sign]] and [[Hawkins-Kennedy test]]). These tests help localize the pathology to the rotator cuff; however, they are not specific for impingement.<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=15866244 | doi=10.1016/j.amjmed.2005.01.040 | volume=118 | issue=5 | title=Shoulder impingement syndrome | journal=The American Journal of Medicine |date=May 2005 |vauthors=Koester MC, George MS, Kuhn JE | pages=452–5}}</ref> Neer sign may also be seen with [[subacromial bursitis]].<ref name="OFP">{{cite journal |title=Physical examination of the shoulder joint-Part I: Supraspinatus rotator cuff muscle clinical testing|last1=Marreez |first1=YM |last2=Forman |first2=MD|last3=Brown|first3=SR|journal=Osteopathic Family Physician|volume=5|issue=3|pages=128–134 |date=May 2013|doi=10.1016/j.osfp.2013.01.005|pmid=|url=}}</ref>
The physician may inject [[lidocaine]] (usually combined with a steroid) into the bursa, and if there is an improved range of motion and decrease in pain, this is considered a positive "Impingement Test". It not only supports the diagnosis for impingement syndrome, but it is also therapeutic.<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=20522833 | doi=10.1177/0363546509359071 | volume=38 | issue=7 | title=Modified impingement test can predict the level of pain reduction after rotator cuff repair | journal=The American Journal of Sports Medicine |date=July 2010 |vauthors=Oh JH, Kim SH, Kim KH, Oh CH, Gong HS | pages=1383–8}}</ref>
Plain x-rays of the shoulder can be used to detect some joint pathology and variations in the bones, including acromioclavicular arthritis, variations in the acromion, and calcification. However, x-rays do not allow visualization of soft tissue and thus hold a low diagnostic value.<ref name="pmid9490991" /> [[Ultrasonography]], [[arthrography]] and [[MRI]] can be used to detect rotator cuff muscle pathology. MRI is the best imaging test prior to arthroscopic surgery.<ref name="pmid9490991" /> Due to lack of understanding of the pathoaetiology, and lack of diagnostic accuracy in the assessment process by many [[physician]]s,<ref name="pmid18838403">{{cite journal |author=Lewis JS. |title=Rotator cuff tendinopathy / subacromial impingement syndrome: Is it time for a new method of assessment? |journal= British Journal of Sports Medicine |date=Oct 17, 2008 |pmid=18838403 |doi=10.1136/bjsm.2008.052183 |volume=43 |issue=4 |pages=259–64}}</ref> several opinions are recommended before intervention.{{Citation needed|date=June 2012}}
==Treatment== Impingement syndrome is usually treated conservatively, but sometimes it is treated with [[arthroscopic surgery]] or [[open surgery]].<ref name="pmid1636936 8">{{cite journal |vauthors=Taheriazam A, Sadatsafavi M, Moayyeri A |title=Outcome predictors in nonoperative management of newly diagnosed subacromial impingement syndrome: a longitudinal study |journal=MedGenMed |volume=7 |issue=1 |pages=63 |year=2005 |pmid=16369368 |pmc=1681371 |doi= |url=http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/496632}}</ref> Conservative treatment includes rest, cessation of painful activity, and [[physical therapy]]. Physical therapy treatments would typically focus at maintaining range of movement, improving posture, strengthening shoulder muscles, and reduction of [[pain]]. To improve pain and function, [[physical therapists]] may employ techniques such as [[joint mobilization]], [[interferential therapy]], [[acupuncture]], [[soft tissue therapy]], therapeutic [[taping]], [[rotator cuff]] strengthening, and [[education]] regarding the cause and mechanism of the condition.{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} [[NSAID]]s and ice packs may be used for pain relief.<ref name="chen03" /><ref name="pmid1636936 8" />
Therapeutic injections of [[corticosteroid]] and [[local anaesthetic]] may be used for persistent impingement syndrome.<ref name="pmid1636936 8" /> The total number of injections is generally limited to three due to possible side effects from the corticosteroid.<ref name="chen03" /> A recent systematic review of [[Levels of evidence|level one evidence]] showed corticoestroid injections only give small and transient pain relief.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mohamadi|first=Amin|last2=Chan|first2=Jimmy J.|last3=Claessen|first3=Femke M. A. P.|last4=Ring|first4=David|last5=Chen|first5=Neal C.|date=January 2017|title=Corticosteroid Injections Give Small and Transient Pain Relief in Rotator Cuff Tendinosis: A Meta-analysis|journal=Clinical Orthopaedics and Related Research|volume=475|issue=1|pages=232–243|doi=10.1007/s11999-016-5002-1|issn=1528-1132|pmc=5174041|pmid=27469590}}</ref>
A number of surgical interventions are available, depending on the nature and location of the pathology. Surgery may be done arthroscopically or as open surgery. The impinging structures may be removed in surgery, and the subacromial space may be widened by resection of the distal clavicle and excision of osteophytes on the under-surface of the acromioclavicular joint.<ref name="chen03" /> Damaged rotator cuff muscles can be surgically repaired.
If the impingement syndrome is caused by restrictions in the scapulo-thoracic region the treatment may be to ease up the relevant rib restrictions (subluxation). One way of doing this is with a small amplitude high velocity thrust at the angle of the subluxed rib whilst stabilising the transverse process of the vertebra that the rib is attached to on the other side of the spine so that the vertebra does not rotate when the thrust is applied to the rib angle. The thrust applied to the rib should be applied in an inferior and anterior direction perpendicular to the plane of the facet of the costo-transverse process joint on the side of the restriction on the rib that is subluxed. (restricted). Once the scapulo-thoracic restrictions are released it may take 48 hours for the scapula to retro-vert and drop inferiorly back into place its normal anatomical position such that pressure on the impinged nerve is returned to a healthy (un-impinged) level.
==History== Impingement syndrome was reported in 1852.<ref name="chen03" /> Impingement of the shoulder was previously thought to be precipitated by shoulder abduction and surgical intervention focused on lateral or total acromionectomy.<ref name="chen03" /><ref name="neer72">{{cite journal |author=Neer CS |title=Anterior acromioplasty for the chronic impingement syndrome in the shoulder: a preliminary report |journal=[[J Bone Joint Surg Am]] |volume=54 |issue=1 |pages=41–50 |date=January 1972 |pmid=5054450 |doi= |url=}}</ref> In 1972, Charles Neer proposed that impingement was due to the anterior third of the acromion and the coracoacromial ligament and suggested surgery should be focused on these areas.<ref name="chen03" /><ref name="neer72" /> The role of anteriorinferior aspect of the acromion in impingement syndrome and excision of parts of the anteriorinferior acromion has become a pivotal part of the surgical treatment of the syndrome.<ref name="chen03" />
==Criticism== Subacromial impingement is not free of criticism. First, the identification of acromion type shows poor intra- and inter-observer reliability.<ref>Zuckerman JD, Kummer FJ, Cuomo F, Greller M.Interobserver reliability of acromial morphology classification: an anatomic study. J Shoulder Elbow Surg 1997; 6:286-7.</ref><ref>Peh WC, Farmer TH, Totty WG. Acromial arch shape:assessment with MR imaging" ''Radiology'' 1995; 195:501-5.</ref> Second, a computerized three-dimensional study failed to support impingement by any portion of the acromion on the rotator cuff tendons in different shoulder positions.<ref>Chang EY, Moses DA, Babb JS, Schweitzer ME. Shoulder impingement: objective 3D shape analysis of acromial morphologic features" ''Radiology'' 2006; 239:497-505.</ref> Third, most partial-thickness cuff tears do not occur on bursal surface fibers, where mechanical abrasion from the acromion does occur.<ref>Loehr J, Uhthoff H. The pathogenesis of degenerative rotator cuff tears. Orthopedic Trans 1987; 11:237-44.</ref><ref>Ogata S, Uhthoff HK. Acromial enthesopathy and rotator cuff tear. A radiologic and histologic postmortem investigation of the coracoacromial arch. Clin Orthop Relat Res 1990; 254:39-48.</ref> Fourth, it has been suggested that bursal surface cuff tears could be responsible for subacromial spurs and not the opposite.<ref>Thompson WO, Debski RE, Boardman ND, et al. A biomechanical analysis of rotator cuff deficiency in a cadaveric model. Am J Sports Med 1996; 24:286-92</ref><ref>Chambler AF, Pitsillides AA, Emery RJ. Acromial spur formation in patients with rotator cuff tears. J Shoulder Elbow Surg. 2003; 12:314-21.</ref><ref>Sarkar K, Taine W, Uhthoff HK. The ultrastructure of the coracoacromial ligament in patients with chronic impingement syndrome. Clin Orthop Relat Res 1990; 254:49-54.</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Ozaki J, Fujimoto S, Nakagawa Y, etal | year = 1988 | title = Tears of the rotator cuff of the shoulder associated with pathological changes in the acromion. A study in cadavera | url = | journal = J Bone Joint Surg Am | volume = 70 | issue = 8| pages = 1224–30 | pmid = 3417708 }}</ref> And finally, there is growing evidence that routine acromioplasty may not be required for successful rotator cuff repair, which would be an unexpected finding if acromial shape had a major role in generating tendon lesions.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Pedowitz RA, Yamaguchi K, Ahmad CS, etal | year = 2012 | title = American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons Clinical Practice Guideline on optimizing the management of rotator cuff problems | url = | journal = J Bone Joint Surg Am | volume = 94 | issue = 2| pages = 163–7 | doi=10.2106/jbjs.k.01368| pmid = 22258004 }}</ref> In summary, despite being a popular theory, the bulk of evidence suggest that subacromial impingement probably does not play a dominant role in many cases of rotator cuff disease.<ref>Arend CF. Ultrasound of the Shoulder. Master Medical Books, 2013</ref>
==See also== * [[Milwaukee shoulder syndrome]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox Venue | name = Internacional Complex | fullname = Kompleksi Internacional | image = | image_caption = | nickname = | location = [[Pezë Helmës]], [[Tirana County|Tiranë]], [[Albania]] | coordinates = {{coord|41|16|08.8|N|19|42|01.0|E|region:ES-M_type:landmark_source:dewiki|display=inline,title}} | type = Sports facility | broke_ground = 2013 | opened = {{Start date and age|2014|8|}} | owner = [[FC Internacional Tirana|Internacional Tirana]] | operator =[[FC Internacional Tirana|Internacional Tirana]] | tenant = [[FC Internacional Tirana|Internacional Tirana]] (2016–) | construction_cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | seating_capacity = 1,000 ([[Pezë Helmës Stadium]])
500 ([[Pezë Helmës Stadium II]]) | former_names = | website = }} '''Internacional Complex''' ({{lang-sq|Kompleksi Internacional}}) is a [[training ground|football training facility]] located in [[Pezë Helmës]], [[Tirana County|Tiranë]], [[Albania]]. The complex consists of two football stadiums, the 1,000 seater [[Pezë Helmës Stadium]] and the 500 seater [[Pezë Helmës Stadium II]]. It is opened and operated by [[FC Internacional Tirana|Internacional Tirana]], and some Albanian football clubs use the facility for training such as [[FK Kukësi|Kukësi]] and [[FK Partizani Tirana|Partizani]]. Many lower league sides use the facility to host games, as both stadiums meet the licensing requirements to host games up to the [[Albanian First Division]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Football venues in Albania}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Internacional Complex}} [[Category:Association football training grounds in Albania]] [[Category:Sports venues in Tirana]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Tirana County]] {{Albania-sports-venue-stub}}

{{infobox brand | logo = | name = JanSport | image = [[Image:Jansportlogo.jpg|250px|The JanSport logo]] | type = [[Backpack]]s | currentowner = [[VF Corporation]]
(1986–present) | slogans = ''The Forever Backpack''
''Discover Freedom'' | origin = | introduced = {{start date and age|1967}}
[[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]], [[United States|U.S.]] | discontinued = | related = | markets = | previousowners = [[Wrangler (jeans)|Blue Bell Overall Company]]
(1967–1986) | trademarkregistrations = | website = [http://jansport.com/ jansport.com] }} '''JanSport''' is an American brand of [[backpack]]s and collegiate apparel, now owned by [[VF Corporation]], one of the world's largest apparel companies.{{cite news | title = Lizzie Jagger teams up with Wrangler for Denim Spa moisturizing jeans | newspaper = Daily News | location = New York City | date = January 17, 2013 | url = http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/fashion/lizzie-jagger-teams-wrangler-moisturizing-jeans-article-1.1241804#ixzz2Jfq2pTut | accessdate = 2013-02-01}} JanSport is the world's largest backpack maker, and together, JanSport and The North Face, also owned by VF Corporation, sell nearly half of all small backpacks sold in the United States. ==History== JanSport was founded in 1967 in [[Seattle, Washington, USA]] by Murray Pletz, his wife Janis "Jan" Lewis (for whom the company is named), and his father Norman Pletz.{{Citation | last = Netherby | first = Steve | title = Who Is Jan Sport? | journal = Field and Stream | volume = 78 | issue = 8 | pages = 116–118 |date=December 1973 }}{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/18/business/skip-yowell-jansport-co-founder-who-blazed-trail-for-backpacks-dies-at-69.html?_r=0 | title=Skip Yowell, JanSport Co-Founder Who Blazed Trail for Backpacks, Dies at 69 | publisher=New York Times | date=October 17, 2015 | accessdate=October 18, 2015 | author=Rachel Abrams}}{{cite web | url=http://www.oregonphotos.com/JanSport-1.html | title=JanSport: Unique and Fun, a Company with Personality | accessdate=October 18, 2015}} JanSport innovated with a panel-loading daypack, unlike traditional top-loading packs. In 1975, JanSport introduced the first convertible travel pack, as well as its signature daypack.{{Cite web|url=http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/JanSport-Inc-Company-History.html|accessdate=2011-06-15|publisher=fundinguniverse.com|title=JanSport, Inc.}} In 1986, VF purchased JanSport's then parent, [[Wrangler (jeans)|Blue Bell]].{{fact|date=February 2014}} JanSport's corporate headquarters is in [[Alameda, California]], at VF Outdoor headquarters, where it shares offices with divisional siblings Lucy and [[The North Face]]. A distribution facility in [[Everett, Washington]], which had opened in 1971, closed in March 2012. JanSport also has a [[warehouse]] in Appleton, Wisconsin, which houses its collegiate apparel division.{{cite news|first=Bruce|last=Horovitz|title=New 'badge' of cool: High-tech, high-fashion backpacks|work=[[USA Today]]|url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/industries/retail/2007-08-19-backpack_N.htm|date=2007-08-20|page=1A|accessdate=2009-09-01}} JanSport started by developing the external frame backpack, which used a metal frame with a cloth packsack attached to it; the products made include technical day packs and internal frame backpacks. Up until the early 1990s, all JanSport packs were made in the United States.[https://www.bizjournals.com/milwaukee/stories/1998/10/26/focus2.html "JanSport Backpacks into Cost-cutting era"]. ''Milwaukee Business Journal.'' Retrieved January 29, 2018.. File:JanSport headquarters.jpg|Jansport headquarters in San Leandro File:Jansport D-3 backpack.jpg|Early 1990s JanSport D-3 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://jansport.com/ JanSport] official web site *[http://www.vfc.com/ VF Corporation] {{DEFAULTSORT:Jansport}} [[Category:Camping equipment manufacturers]] [[Category:Clothing companies of the United States]] [[Category:Hiking equipment]] [[Category:Luggage brands]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies based in California]] [[Category:Companies based in San Leandro, California]] [[Category:American companies established in 1967]] [[Category:Clothing companies established in 1967]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1967]] [[Category:1967 establishments in Washington (state)]] [[Category:American brands]]

Jordanian athletes competed in three sports: athletics, powerlifting and table tennis. Among the competitors was [[Maha Barghouti]], a table tennis player who won Jordan's first Paralympic gold medal at the [[2000 Summer Paralympics]]. The team left for Beijing on September 29.{{cite web |title=Competing in sports gave me a life: Jordan's first Paralympics gold medalist |work=[[Xinhua News Agency]] |date=2008-08-31 |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-08/31/content_9743534.htm |accessdate=2008-08-31 }} == Medalists == {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !
