16,605 (1983–1988)
20,240 (1988–1995)
19,289 (1995–present) |}} '''Scotiabank Saddledome''' is a multi-use [[indoor arena]] in [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]], Canada. Located in [[Stampede Park]] in the southeast end of [[downtown Calgary]], the Saddledome was built in 1983 to replace the [[Stampede Corral]] as the home of the [[Calgary Flames]] of the [[National Hockey League]], and to host [[Ice hockey at the 1988 Winter Olympics|ice hockey]] and [[figure skating at the 1988 Winter Olympics|figure skating]] at the [[1988 Winter Olympics]]. The facility also hosts concerts, conferences and other sporting championships, and events for the [[Calgary Exhibition and Stampede]]. It underwent a major renovation in 1994–95 and sold its [[naming rights]], during which its original name of '''Olympic Saddledome''' was changed to '''Canadian Airlines Saddledome'''. The facility was given the name '''Pengrowth Saddledome''' in 2000, after [[Pengrowth Management Ltd.]] signed a ten-year agreement. It adopted its current name in October 2010 as [[Scotiabank]] signed on as title sponsor. The Saddledome is owned by the City of Calgary, who leases it to the Saddledome Foundation, a [[non-profit organization]], to oversee its operation. Since 1996, it has been managed by the Flames. The Saddledome was damaged during the [[2013 Alberta floods]] but was repaired and reopened in time for the [[2013–14 NHL season]]. The arena's roof is shaped like a [[saddle]], thus earning the name "Saddledome". == Construction == Calgary had been served for 30 years by the [[Stampede Corral]] when the [[Calgary Flames]] arrived in 1980. With a total capacity of 8,700, the Corral was the largest arena in Canada west of Toronto in 1950,{{cite news |last=Toth |first=Dan |title=Shootout at the Stampede Corral |work=Calgary Sun |date=2005-02-12 |page=10}} but had fallen below major league standards by the 1970s. The Corral was deemed insufficient for the [[National Hockey League]] (NHL) in 1977, leading the [[World Hockey Association]]'s [[Calgary Cowboys]] to fold rather than hope to be a team selected to merge with the NHL.{{cite book |last=Zeman |first=Gary |title=Alberta on Ice |year=1985 |page=90 |publisher=GMS Ventures |isbn=0-9692320-0-4}} Calgary's bid to host the [[1988 Winter Olympics]], coupled with the arrival of the Flames, drove the need to build a new arena. City Council debated the merits of several locations for the city's new Olympic Coliseum, and narrowed their choices down to two areas in the [[Victoria Park, Calgary|Victoria Park]] neighbourhood on the east end of downtown.{{cite news |last=Pratt |first=Sheila |title=Coliseum decision today — east end has edge |work=Calgary Herald |page=A1 |date=1981-03-03}} Two other sites, one on the west end of downtown, and a late bid by several businessmen pushing to build the arena in the northern suburb of [[Airdrie, Alberta|Airdrie]] were also considered.{{cite news |last=Tennant |first=Jack |title=Airdrie logical site for coliseum |work=Calgary Sun |page=5 |date=1981-02-12}} [[Image:Saddledome from Calgary Tower.JPG|thumb|left|250px|The Saddledome's location within Stampede Park, as seen from the [[Calgary Tower]]]] The Victoria Park Community Association fought the bid to build the arena in their neighborhood, threatening to oppose the city's Olympic bid if necessary.{{cite news |last=St. Laurent |first=Steve |title=Residents will fight coliseum |work=Calgary Herald |date=March 2, 1981 |page=A1}} City Council voted on March 3, 1981 to build the proposed 20,000 seat arena on the Stampede grounds, immediately east of the Corral and south of Victoria Park.{{cite news |last=Warden |first=Kathryn |title=Stampede picked for coliseum |work=Calgary Herald |date=1981-03-04 |page=A1}} The community continued to fight the city over rezoning the land to allow for the new arena amidst fears of traffic congestion in their neighbourhood which resulted in numerous costly delays to the start of construction.{{cite news |last=Pratt |first=Sheila |title=Klein tries end run in coliseum battle |work=Calgary Herald |date=1981-07-25 |page=A1}} In a bid to end the battle, Mayor [[Ralph Klein]] asked the provincial government in July 1981 to take over the land designated for the arena to bypass the appeals process and force approval.{{cite news |last=Cotton |first=Crosbie |title=Klein's action may guarantee Games |work=Calgary Herald |date=1981-07-28 |page=B1}} The province supported the city amidst protests by community associations and invoked rarely used powers to overrule planning regulations, allowing construction to begin.{{cite news |title=Final hurdle is cleared for coliseum |work=Calgary Herald |date=1981-07-29 |page=A1}} The following day, on July 29, 1981, builders began construction of the arena.{{cite news |last=Cotton |first=Crosbie |title=Work starts on coliseum site |work=Calgary Herald |date=1980-07-30 |page=B1}} The [[International Olympic Committee]] was impressed that the project was underway, as noted in the XV Olympic Winter Games official report which stated "The fact that this facility was already being built added credibility to (Calgary's) bid and proved to be a positive factor in demonstrating Calgary's commitment to hosting the Games".{{cite news|last=Remington |first=Robert |url=http://www.canada.com/calgaryherald/news/story.html?id=bb367c51-527e-4abc-b61a-39821fa3f0f9 |title=Sensational Saddledome helped define Calgary |work=Calgary Herald |page=A3 |date=2008-10-12 |accessdate=2008-10-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090122112758/http://www.canada.com/calgaryherald/news/story.html?id=bb367c51-527e-4abc-b61a-39821fa3f0f9 |archivedate=2009-01-22 |df= }} The facility was designed by Graham McCourt Architects. While they set out to design a unique building, the idea of a western theme never occurred to Barry Graham or his team. The [[saddle roof|roof]] of the building was designed to be a reverse [[hyperbolic paraboloid]], allowing for a pillar free view from all seats and reducing the interior volume by up to one-third when compared to traditional arenas,{{cite web |url=http://www.pengrowthsaddledome.com/b_design.html |title=Building Design |publisher=Saddledome Foundation |accessdate=2008-10-21}} resulting in reduced heating, lighting and maintenance costs, plus the floating roof can flex to compensate for the city's frequent temperature fluctuations. When the design was unveiled, the roof was immediately referred to as being saddle-shaped. Of 1,270 entries submitted in a contest to name the arena, 735 involved the word Saddle. The winning name in the contest, ''Olympic Saddledome'', was drawn from a hat filled with several similar saddle-themed names. At the time the name received a tepid reception from some, including the chairman of Calgary's Olympic Organizing Committee (OCO), Frank King, who was quoted as saying "It is neither Olympic nor western, and it's not even dome". The designers won several architectural and engineering awards for their work on the Saddledome, and were honoured by the [[Royal Architectural Institute of Canada]] at its millennium celebration of architecture in 2000.{{cite web|url=http://www.aaa.ab.ca/pages/public/csaa/csaa-30.aspx |title=Olympic Saddledome |publisher=Alberta Association of Architects |accessdate=2010-01-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080416224920/http://www.aaa.ab.ca/pages/public/csaa/csaa-30.aspx |archivedate=2008-04-16 |df= }} As of 2008, the Saddledome was still reported as the world record holder for the longest spanning hyperbolic paraboloid concrete shell. The Saddledome was featured on the cover of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine on September 27, 1987, for an article discussing the city of Calgary and the upcoming 1988 Olympics.{{cite journal |title=Welcoming the world |work=Time Magazine |date=1987-09-27 |page=cover |issn=0040-781X}} The location of the Saddledome within Stampede Park allows for easy access to Calgary's [[CTrain]] light rail transit system via the [[Victoria Park/Stampede (C-Train)|Victoria Park/Stampede station]] that stands parallel to [[Macleod Trail (Calgary)|Macleod Trail]]. The CTrain station, BMO Centre, Stampede Corral and Saddledome are all connected via a [[+15|Plus 15]] pedestrian [[skyway]]. Direct vehicle access is gained from the north via 5th Street East or Olympic Way.{{cite web |url=http://www.premier.alberta.ca/royalvisit/images/StampedeParkMap.pdf |format=PDF |title=Stampede Park map |publisher=Government of Alberta |accessdate=2010-01-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5n12Le0Od?url=http://www.premier.alberta.ca/royalvisit/images/StampedeParkMap.pdf |archivedate=2010-01-24 |df= }} ==History== [[File:Calgary skyline.jpg|thumb|204x204px|The Saddledome and [[Calgary]] skyline at night]] The arena was initially projected to cost $60 million to build, and later revised to over $80 million.{{cite news |title=Saddledome's a cinch to please |work=Calgary Herald |date=1983-10-15 |page=G1}} Attempts to fast track construction resulted in a $16 million cost overrun, resulting in a final cost of $97.7 million and an eight-month delay in its completion. Builders faced delays while building the roof as numerous adjustments were required to fit the giant concrete slabs between the array of cables that held them in place.{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gu8gAAAAIBAJ&sjid=AHMFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1274,5728567 |title=Calgary Saddledome: 10 months overdue, $16.5 million over |work=New London Day |date=1983-09-20 |accessdate=2010-01-16 |page=38}} Upset with the excess cost, [[Opposition (parliamentary)|opposition]] politicians in Alberta demanded a public hearing into the issue.{{cite web |last=Rose |first=Michael |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=SRUyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=RKUFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5761,2892000 |title=Calgary Olympics: Trying to avoid Montreal's example |work=Montreal Gazette |date=1983-07-30 |accessdate=2010-01-16 |page=B5}} A hearing conducted by the city placed much of the blame on the project manager, while the city and province were required to pay the additional costs.{{cite web |last=Adams |first=Jeff |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-zA0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=MPUIAAAAIBAJ&pg=1642,2979213 |title=Report questions Olympic chief's competence |work=Ottawa Citizen |date=1984-10-16 |accessdate=2010-01-16 |page=C1}} When it opened on October 15, 1983, the Olympic Saddledome served to boost the morale of a city that was experiencing a significant downturn as a result of the international oil market collapse, high interest rates, and the federal government's [[National Energy Policy]]. During the first event, an NHL game between the Flames and the [[Edmonton Oilers]], the standard of [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Pierre Trudeau]] was the first thing booed by a population upset with the government's policies.{{cite news |last=Wood |first=Larry |title=Glass, pigeons crash opening clambake |work=Calgary Herald |date=1983-10-16 |page=E1}} The Oilers defeated the Flames 4–3 in front of a sold out crowd of nearly 17,000 fans.{{cite news |last=Duhatschek |first=Eric |title=Saddledome infested with 'Rat' |work=Calgary Herald |page=E1 |date=1983-10-16}} The initial [[seating capacity]] was 16,605 for hockey as the upper loges were not immediately completed.{{cite book |last=Mummery |first=Bob |title=Countdown to the Stanley Cup |page=39 |publisher=Polestar Book Publishers |year=1989 |isbn=0-919591-48-5}} As the Olympics neared, the Calgary organizing committee spent $1 million to add over 2,600 seats to the upper loges in a bid to alleviate a scandal that resulted from the organizing committee giving its partners and sponsors preferential treatment in ticket sales.{{cite journal |last=Reed |first=J.D. |title=Games on the range |work=Time Magazine |date=1987-09-27 |page=17 |issn=0040-781X}} With a capacity of 20,016, the [[International Ice Hockey Federation]] noted that it was the largest arena ever used at the Winter Games, and called the facility "the finest international rink in the world"{{cite book |last=Podnieks |first=Andrew |title=Canada's Olympic Hockey History 1920–2010 |publisher=Fenn Publishing |location=Toronto |page=149 |isbn=1-55168-323-7}} The [[International Olympic Committee]] praised the city's commitment to hosting the Olympics, noting in its official report that constructing the arena prior to being awarded the Games lent credibility to Calgary's bid and positively influenced voters. The Saddledome was the first arena in North America designed to accommodate the larger international [[Ice hockey rink|ice surface]]{{cite web |url=http://espn.go.com/travel/stadium/_/s/nhl/id/3/scotiabank-saddledome |title=Scotiabank Saddledome |publisher=ESPN |accessdate=2011-10-30}} (international rinks are 13 feet wider than NHL rinks). The Saddledome reached its highest capacity in the early '90s at 20,230. [[Image:Pengrowth Saddledome lacrosse.jpg|thumb|left|Inside the Saddledome during a [[Calgary Roughnecks]] game]] The Flames petitioned the City of Calgary and the Saddledome Foundation to upgrade the facility in 1994, requesting renovations to add additional luxury boxes and a new club section. The Flames insisted the upgrades were necessary for the team to remain viable in the arena. They argued it was important that their landlord bring the arena up to the higher standards they felt was required.{{cite news |title=Moving never option, Doc Seaman claims |work=Calgary Herald |date=1994-08-09 |page=A1}} The team lobbied City Council in the hope it would agree to fund the majority of the $18 million renovation using federal infrastructure funds. At the same time, they rejected a counter proposal for applying a ticket surcharge to pay the cost.{{cite news |last=Stelnhart |first=David |work=Calgary Herald |title=Council approves Saddledome deal |date=1994-03-22 |page=A1}} Media reports claimed the team was considering relocating out of Calgary if council did not agree. Flames' owners denied the reports, but said they had threatened to build a new rink elsewhere in the city. City Council supported the Flames' proposal in a 9–6 vote following several months of negotiations.{{cite news |last=Megrath |first=Vickie |last2=Miller |first2=Mark |title=Council OK's 'Dome deal |work=Calgary Sun |date=1994-03-22 |page=4}} Renovations occurred between 1994 and 1995 and saw the addition of 41 new luxury suites at the top of the lower bowl, an 1,172 seat club section, a new restaurant, expanded offices for the Flames, Saddledome management and [[Hockey Canada]], as well as a significant restructuring of the public concourse and a new parkade structure.{{cite news |title=Dome improvement |work=Calgary Sun |date=1994-03-20 |page=17}} The arena remained operational until the spring of 1995 despite ongoing construction, but was closed entirely between April and October 1995.{{cite news |last=Stewart |first=Monte |title=It's chaos, but the shows go on |work=Calgary Herald |date=1994-08-10 |page=A1}} The Saddledome officially reopened on October 25, 1995 for the Flames' first home game of the [[1995–96 NHL season]].{{cite web |url=http://flames.nhl.com/club/page.htm?id=40685 |title=Flames history |publisher=Calgary Flames Hockey Club |accessdate=2010-01-20}} Prior to its reopening, the Flames signed a deal with [[Canadian Airlines]] to rename the facility. Under a twenty-year agreement worth approximately $1 million per year, the arena became the Canadian Airlines Saddledome. Removing the "Olympic" moniker was controversial with both the public and City Council, though the city voted in favour of the deal which included the donation of a portion of the naming rights to fund amateur sports within the city.{{cite news |last=Dolik |first=Helen |title=Deal made to rename 'Dome |work=Calgary Herald |date=1995-07-19 |page=A1}} The arena was renamed again in 2000 when Canadian Airlines was acquired by [[Air Canada]] and ceased operations. [[Pengrowth Energy Trust|Pengrowth Management Ltd.]] signed a ten-year agreement that gave the facility the name Pengrowth Saddledome.{{cite web |last=Francis |first=Eric |url=http://www.canoe.ca/HockeyCalgaryArchive/jun30_tha.html |title=That's the ticket! |work=Calgary Sun |date=2000-06-30 |accessdate=2010-01-16}} The arena has received cosmetic upgrades in recent years. In 2004, the Flames spent $1 million on a [[Light-emitting diode|LED]] "power ring" display that lines the facing of the second level. The [[JumboTron]] that was installed in 1995 was replaced in 2006 with a new [[High-definition video|high definition]] scoreboard.{{cite web|url=http://www.canada.com/calgaryherald/news/story.html?id=58c4dfd1-dd93-408a-805d-479342340ac5&k=76617 |title=Lights out for JumboTron |work=Calgary Herald |date=2006-12-13 |accessdate=2010-01-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604114553/http://www.canada.com/calgaryherald/news/story.html?id=58c4dfd1-dd93-408a-805d-479342340ac5&k=76617 |archivedate=2011-06-04 |df= }} Manufactured by [[Daktronics]], the display has twelve screens and two LED ribbons,{{cite web |url=http://www.daktronics.com/ProductsServices/PhotoGallery/Pages/default.aspx?photoID=WP-13088&keywords=Saddledome&filters= |title=Photo Gallery – Saddledome |publisher=Daktronics |accessdate=2010-01-23}} and is called the [[Enmax]] Energy Board. ===2013 flood=== [[File:Saddledome flood seats.jpg|thumb|right|Flooding of the lower bowl reached the eighth row of seating.]] The Saddledome was one of many buildings impacted by the [[2013 Alberta floods]]. The flooding of the [[Elbow River|Elbow]] and [[Bow River|Bow]] Rivers swamped many areas of the city, including Stampede Park where the Saddledome is located. The event level of the arena was filled with water, also wrecking the [[High-definition video|high definition]] scoreboard that had been sitting on the rink floor during the summer downtime, while the dressing rooms and control room for the video replay screen were swamped.{{cite news |url=https://www.tsn.ca/nhl/story/?id=425999 |title=Saddledome, Stampede Grounds hit by flooding in Alberta |publisher=The Sports Network |date=2013-06-21 |accessdate=2013-06-21}} At a press conference held on June 22, 2013, team president Ken King stated that the arena had flooded up to the eighth row and that the event level of the facility was a "total loss". He added that the team's equipment and some memorabilia had also been destroyed, but expressed confidence that the facility would be repaired and ready in time for the October start to the [[2013–14 Calgary Flames season]].{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/hockey/nhl/story/2013/06/22/sp-nhl-calgary-flames-flooding-saddledome.html |title=Flames say lower part of Saddledome 'total loss' from flooding |publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation |date=2013-06-22 |accessdate=2013-06-22}} Repairs to the facility forced the cancellation of all concerts and agricultural events scheduled for the 2013 [[Calgary Stampede]].{{cite news |last=Toneguzzi |first=Mario |url=http://www.calgaryherald.com/entertainment/Kiss+Jepsen+McGraw+Dixie+Chicks+Saddledome+concerts/8607227/story.html |title=Kiss, Jepsen, Dixie Chicks, Saddledome concerts cancelled by Calgary Stampede |work=Calgary Herald |date=2013-07-02 |accessdate=2013-07-02}} Crews worked around the clock to repair the facility; Saddledome director of building operations Robert Blanchard estimated that 650,000 man hours of work was performed on the facility and noted that they had compressed a six-month project into two. The facility was granted its occupancy permit in late August, and the first event following the Saddledome's reopening was an [[Eagles (band)|Eagles]] concert on September 11. The first hockey game was September 14, a Flames pre-season contest.{{cite news |url=https://www.tsn.ca/nhl/story/?id=431244 |title=Saddledome prepares to host concerts, hockey after flood |publisher=The Sports Network |date=2013-09-05 |accessdate=2013-09-05}} ==Events== [[File:2009 Brier Saddledome.JPG|thumb|right|The Saddledome hosted the [[2009 Tim Hortons Brier]]]] As the home of the Flames, the Saddledome hosted the [[37th National Hockey League All-Star Game|1985 NHL All-Star Game]],{{cite news |last=Duhatschek |first=Eric |title=Lemieux shrugs off sour Grapes |work=Calgary Herald |date=1985-02-13 |page=E1}} and the [[2000 NHL Entry Draft]].{{cite web |last=Wigge |first=Larry |url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-28012587_ITM |title=Rolling the dice |work=The Sporting News |date=2000-06-26 |accessdate=2010-01-16}} The Flames have played three [[Stanley Cup]] Finals series in the Saddledome: [[1986 Stanley Cup Finals|1986]], [[1989 Stanley Cup Finals|1989]] and [[2004 Stanley Cup Finals|2004]].{{cite book |title=2009–10 Calgary Flames Media Guide |publisher=Calgary Flames Hockey Club |last=Hanlon |first=Peter |last2=Kelso |first2=Sean |url=http://flames.nhl.com/club/page.htm?id=40390 |format=PDF |year=2009 |pages=8–9}} The arena is also the home of the [[Calgary Hitmen]] of the [[Western Hockey League]] (WHL). The Hitmen won the [[Ed Chynoweth Cup|President's Trophy]] in 1999 before a WHL playoff record crowd of 17,139.{{cite news |last=Sportak |first=Randy |title=Memorial Drive |work=Calgary Herald |page=S2}} Playing in the largest arena in the WHL,{{Cite book|editor=Flett, Cory |editor2=Watts, Jessie|title=2008–09 WHL Guide|publisher=Western Hockey League|pages=33–138}} the Hitmen also hold league records for overall attendance (362,227 in [[2004–05 WHL season|2004–05]]),{{cite book|editor=Flett, Cory |editor2=Watts, Jessie|title=2008–09 WHL Guide|publisher=Western Hockey League|page=219}} as well as single game (19,305 in [[2007–08 WHL season|2007–08]]).{{cite web|url=http://whl.ca/calgary-hitmen-set-new-whl-attendance-record-p126161 |title=Calgary Hitmen set new attendance record |publisher=Western Hockey League |date=2008-03-17 |accessdate=2010-01-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150617062254/http://whl.ca/calgary-hitmen-set-new-whl-attendance-record-p126161 |archivedate=June 17, 2015 }} The Saddledome is also the home of the [[Calgary Roughnecks]] of the [[National Lacrosse League]] (NLL) and hosted the 2005 [[National Lacrosse League All-Star Game|NLL All-Star Game]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nll.com/laxhistory.php |title=League history (select 2005 from drop down menu) |publisher=National Lacrosse League |accessdate=2010-01-16}} It has twice hosted the NLL [[Champion's Cup]] game: [[2004 NLL season|2004]] and [[2009 NLL season|2009]], both Calgary victories.{{cite web |url=https://www.tsn.ca/lacrosse/story/?id=278890 |title=Roughnecks defeat Titans to win second NLL championship |publisher=The Sports Network |date=2009-05-16 |accessdate=2010-01-16}} The stadium was one of the venues for the [[2012 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships]]. The opening of the Saddledome allowed Calgary to host major musical acts that were bypassing the city in the early 1980s, because the city's existing facilities were not large enough to accommodate the industry's top performers.{{cite news |last=McCoy |first=Heath |title='Dome saddles up big acts |work=Calgary Herald |date=2008-10-13 |page=C1}} The [[Moody Blues]] were the first musical act to appear with [[Stevie Ray Vaughan]] opening, in November 1983, while [[Rod Stewart]] has made the most appearances in the Dome, 11.{{cite news |title=By the numbers |work=Calgary Herald |date=2008-10-12 |page=A3}} Many other top acts have made stops in the Saddledome, however the inability of the roof to support the massive light, speaker and special effect rigs that some performers currently use has led the city to again be bypassed for some major tours.{{cite news |last=Fekete |first=Jason |title=Is the sun setting on Alberta's NHL rinks? |work=Calgary Herald |date=2009-04-12 |page=B1}} In addition to [[Ice hockey at the 1988 Winter Olympics|hockey]] and [[Figure skating at the 1988 Winter Olympics|figure skating]] at the 1988 Olympics,[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1988/orw1988pt1.pdf 1988 Winter Olympics official report.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110114080921/http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1988/orw1988pt1.pdf |date=2011-01-14 }} Part 1. pp. 152-7. the Saddledome has been the site of numerous major national and international events. The facility has hosted [[Tim Hortons Brier|Brier]], the Canadian men's [[curling]] championship, on four occasions ([[1997 Labatt Brier|1997]], [[2002 Nokia Brier|2002]], [[2009 Tim Hortons Brier|2009]] and [[2015 Tim Hortons Brier|2015]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.curling.ca/content/NewsAndFeatures/news26.asp |title=Calgary to Stage 2009 Tim Hortons Brier; Tim Hortons Renews Sponsorship Through 2010 |publisher=Canadian Curling Association |date=2007-10-12 |accessdate=2010-01-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100220051523/http://www.curling.ca/content/NewsAndFeatures/news26.asp |archivedate=February 20, 2010 }} It also hosted the women's championship, the [[Scotties Tournament of Hearts|Tournament of Hearts]] in [[1995 Scott Tournament of Hearts|1995]].{{cite news |title=Veterans will fight it out at Tournament of Hearts |work=Kitchener Record |date=1995-01-31 |page=D2}} The [[2006 World Figure Skating Championships]] was also held in the arena.{{cite web |url=http://www.isufs.org/results/wc2006/ |title=ISU World Figure Skating Championships 2006 |publisher=International Skating Union |accessdate=2010-01-23}} The WWF pay-per-view event [[In Your House 16: Canadian Stampede]] was also held at the Saddledome in July 1997. Among non-sporting events, the Saddledome most recently hosted a public address by the [[Dalai Lama]] in 2009 that was attended by 15,000 people.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/calgary/story/2009/09/30/calgary-dalai-lama-white-hat.html |title=Dalai Lama talks peace in Calgary |publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation |date=2009-09-30 |accessdate=2010-01-23}} In 2005, [[Queen Elizabeth II]] attended a celebration of Alberta's centennial at the Saddledome. It has also hosted [[Professional Bull Riders|PBR]] [[Built Ford Tough Series|Bud Light Cup]] events; in 1998 and 1999 the event was known as "Cody Snyder's Bullbustin'", and in 2000 and 2001 the event was called the Professional Bull Riders Canadian Open. The Saddledome has also been a host for PBR Canada{{cite web|author=Tyler Thomson |url=http://www.pbrcanada.com |title=Home |publisher=PBR Canada |date= |accessdate=2013-02-22}} events. On October 3, 2016, the Saddledome hosted a [[National Basketball Association]] preseason game between the [[Toronto Raptors]] and [[Denver Nuggets]]. On July 21, 2012, the Saddledome hosted an [[Ultimate Fighting Championship]] event, which is [[2012 in UFC#UFC 149: Faber vs. Barão|UFC 149]]. Six years later, on July 28, 2018, the Saddledome hosted another UFC event, which is [[UFC on Fox: Alvarez vs. Poirier 2]]. The arena was also the site of the [[Liberal Party of Canada leadership election, 1990|1990 Liberal Party leadership convention]]. ==Amenities== The Saddledome seats 19,289 for hockey and lacrosse, with different capacities for other events depending on the arena's configuration.{{cite web |url=http://www.pengrowthsaddledome.com/atoz.html#s |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080903010501/http://www.pengrowthsaddledome.com/atoz.html#s |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-09-03 |title=Saddledome A to Z (S) |publisher=Saddledome Foundation |accessdate=2010-01-23 }} It has 72 luxury suites, 41 of which were constructed at the top of the lower bowl in 1995 and 31 were constructed at the top of the second level when the facility was built. There are also six party suites on the corners of the upper loges that are rented on an event by event basis.{{cite web|url=http://flames.nhl.com/club/page.htm?id=40763 |title=Luxury suites |publisher=Calgary Flames Hockey Club |accessdate=2010-01-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100203171806/http://flames.nhl.com/club/page.htm?id=40763 |archivedate=2010-02-03 |df= }} Sections 115 through 122 of the lower bowl form the Chrysler Club and offers in-seat concession service at Flames games.{{cite web|url=http://flames.nhl.com/club/page.htm?id=40762 |title=Seating map and pricing |publisher=Calgary Flames Hockey Club |accessdate=2010-01-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100107033723/http://flames.nhl.com/club/page.htm?id=40762 |archivedate=2010-01-07 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.pengrowthsaddledome.com/atoz.html#c |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080903010501/http://www.pengrowthsaddledome.com/atoz.html#c |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-09-03 |title=Saddledome A to Z (C) |publisher=Saddledome Foundation |accessdate=2010-01-23 }} The Chrysler Club features a private dining room available during Flames games, large concerts and private events.{{cite web |url=http://www.pengrowthsaddledome.com/restaurants.html |title=The Avison Young Club |publisher=Saddledome Foundation |accessdate=2010-01-23}} Dutton's Canadian Lounge is a sports bar located at the west entrance to the building.{{cite web |url=http://www.pengrowthsaddledome.com/r_duttons.html |title=Dutton's Canadian Lounge |publisher=Saddledome Foundation |accessdate=2010-01-23}} There are three additional restaurants within the facility: The [[HSBC]] Saddleroom Restaurant, the Alumni Lounge and the King Club. The Iconic Platinum Club is a 188-seat executive club accessible with a purchased membership. It features a private bar and restaurant as well as a fully functional business centre.{{cite web |url=http://www.pengrowthsaddledome.com/r_execlub.html |title=Fairmont Platinum Club |publisher=Saddledome Foundation |accessdate=2010-01-23}} ==Saddledome Foundation== The City of Calgary established the Saddledome Foundation in 1983 and leased the arena for 50-years to the non-profit organization. Its mandate was to "oversee the operation in a manner that protects taxpayers and benefits amateur sports at the local, provincial and national level". The foundation is made up of a board of nine directors: three appointed by the city, three appointed by the province, and one each appointed by the Calgary Olympic Development Association (now [[Canadian Winter Sport Institute|WinSport Canada]]), Hockey Canada and the Calgary Exhibition and Stampede.{{cite web |url=http://www.pengrowthsaddledome.com/foundmain.html |title=Saddledome Foundation |publisher=Saddledome Foundation |accessdate=2010-01-20}} The foundation contracted the Stampede to manage the arena, and through its lease agreements with the Stampede and the Flames, earned 15% of gross concession sales, 50% of net income from luxury suites and executive seating and investment income on the arena's revenues. The Flames signed a 20-year lease in 1983 that earned them 70% of advertising revenues and 90% of ticket revenues. The Stampede earned 85% of concession revenues and all revenue from parking. As part of the 1994 deal with the city, the Flames bought out the Stampede's contract for $20 million and took over management of the facility. While the city and Saddledome Foundation paid for the 1994–95 renovations, the new agreement required the Flames to pay for future arena maintenance and repairs, as well as any further renovations. The Flames agreed to manage the arena for 20 years and to contribute $14.5 million toward amateur sport in the city over that time. The Saddledome Foundation retains the responsibility of distributing funds to amateur sport. From its inception through 2007, it had allocated over $20 million toward this cause.{{cite web |url=http://www.pengrowthsaddledome.com/pdf/AnnualReport2006_07.pdf |title=2005/2006 Board of Director's annual report |publisher=Saddledome Foundation |year=2007 |accessdate=2010-01-20}} ==Future== The Saddledome is one of the oldest arenas in the NHL, fueling speculation that it is due to be replaced. Only [[Madison Square Garden]] in [[New York City]] and the [[Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum]] in [[Uniondale, New York]] are older than the Saddledome; however, both arenas underwent major renovations in the 2010s, and the [[New York Islanders]] are scheduled to move into a [[Belmont Park Arena|new arena]] in [[Elmont, New York]] in 2021. Flames president and chief executive officer Ken King said in 2008 that plans for a new arena were "five to eight years away" creating the expectation that the team hoped to have a new arena built for when their lease was due to expire in 2014, but such plans never came to fruition.{{Cite news |last=Sportak |first=Randy |url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Columnists/Sportak/2007/08/23/4440643-sun.html |title=Home sweet 'Dome no more? |work=Calgary Sun |date=2008-08-23 |accessdate=2008-10-23}} Team chairman [[N. Murray Edwards|Murray Edwards]] argues that the ability of the facility to host major events and concerts are growing increasingly limited as the facility ages. Along with Edwards, sports financial analysts also note that newer arenas generate far more revenue for their teams than the Saddledome does for the Flames. It is expected that any new arena would also be located either on the Stampede Grounds or elsewhere in downtown Calgary. While NHL Commissioner [[Gary Bettman]] has lobbied on behalf of both the Flames and the Oilers for government support, Calgary mayor [[Naheed Nenshi]] and [[alderman]] John Mar have stated their opposition using taxpayer money to help fund a new arena.{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/calgary-flames-keeping-a-low-profile-on-plans-to-replace-saddledome/article8146553/|title=Calgary Flames keeping a low profile on plans to replace Saddledome|author1=Allan Maki |author2=Dawn Walton |lastauthoramp=yes |date=1 February 2013|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|accessdate=2 February 2013|location=Calgary}}{{cite news |last=Logan |first=Shawn |title=Timeline frozen for new arena |work=Calgary Sun |date=2008-10-23}} King stated that the Flames have concepts and designs for a new building, but are not ready to release them. Some of the plans being considered for Stampede Park would include lowering the city's [[C-train]] [[light rail transit]] line below ground and run straight into a new facility. In 2015, Calgary Sports and Entertainment proposed [[CalgaryNEXT]]—a sports complex in the western downtown area that would feature a new arena and football stadium to replace the Saddledome and [[McMahon Stadium]].{{cite news |last=Toneguzzi |first=Mario |title=Flames' aspirations were just too big for Stampede Park |work=Calgary Herald |date=August 19, 2015 |accessdate=August 27, 2015 |page=A6 |url=http://calgaryherald.com/news/local-news/flames-aspirations-were-just-too-big-for-stampede-park-to-accommodate}} The proposal was shot down by Calgary's city council in 2017, who voted to support a "plan B" of a new arena on a site adjacent to the existing Saddledome, which is currently used as a parking lot for the Stampede grounds.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/calgary-council-plan-b-calgary-next-still-sleeping-1.4083787|title=CalgaryNext on life support as council votes unanimously in favour of 'Plan B' near Saddledome|work=CBC News|access-date=2017-09-28|language=en}} On September 12, 2017, Flames president [[Ken King (ice hockey)|Ken King]] stated that the team was no longer pursuing the arena, as "we've been working for a long time trying to come up with a formula that really works to replace this building and we really put our best foot forward and I’ve come to the conclusion sadly and I’m very disappointed that I don't think we can make a deal that works for us".{{Cite news|url=https://www.tsn.ca/king-says-flames-are-no-longer-pursuing-new-arena-1.854741|title=King says Flames are no longer pursuing new arena|date=2017-09-12|work=TSN|access-date=2017-09-13}} Mayor [[Naheed Nenshi]] subsequently proposed a partnership wherein portions of the cost of "plan B" would be covered by the city, and the rest covered by the team ownership and user surcharges. King objected to this proposal.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/calgary-city-council-flames-negotiations-deal-1.4291316|title=Calgary Flames CEO says city's arena proposal would leave team footing full bill|work=CBC News|access-date=2017-09-28|language=en}} Critics alleged that the Flames had been trying to use the issue of a new arena to influence the [[Calgary municipal election, 2017|2017 municipal elections]], where Nenshi was elected for a third term as mayor of Calgary. King denied that this was the case, stating that "we did not raise this as an election issue: it became an election issue".{{Cite news|url=https://beta.theglobeandmail.com/sports/hockey/calgary-flames-president-keeps-mum-on-dispute-over-new-arena/article36394415/|title=Calgary Flames president keeps mum on dispute over new arena|date=2017-09-25|work=The Globe and Mail|access-date=2017-09-28|language=en-CA}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/sports/new-calgary-flames-arena-in-limbo-after-mayor-s-re-election-1.3636787|title=New Calgary Flames arena in limbo after mayor's re-election|last=Spencer|first=Donna|date=2017-10-17|agency=Canadian Press|access-date=2017-11-14|language=en-CA}} [[File:Saddledome Panorama.JPG|centre|thumb|750px|Panoramic view of the interior of the Saddledome, and the "C of Red", prior to a Calgary Flames playoff game]] ==See also== * [[Arizona Veterans Memorial Coliseum]] * [[Capital Centre]] * [[London Velopark]] * [[Hyperboloid structure]] * [[Tensile architecture]] * [[Thin-shell structure]] * [[List of indoor arenas in Canada]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category-inline|Scotiabank Saddledome}} * {{Official website|http://www.scotiabanksaddledome.com}} * [http://www.arcaro.org/tension/album/saddledome.htm Construction Details] * [http://www.canaconstruction.com/projects/olympic-saddledome/ Cana Construction Profile] {{Navboxes||list1= {{s-start-collapsible|header={{s-sta|et}}}} {{s-bef|before=[[Stampede Corral]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Home of the

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
{{Redirect|Pup tent|the Luna album|Pup Tent}} [[File:Zeltbahn bundeswehr.png|thumb|Schematics of a German Bundeswehr shelter half ("Zeltbahn")]] [[File:Pup Tent at Fort Benning-Overstreet.jpg|thumb|U.S. Army pup tent in World War II, made with two shelter halves]] A '''shelter-half''' ([[UK]], [[Australia]], and [[United States]]; the German equivalent, dating from before the Second World War, being the '''[Dreiecks]Zeltbahn''' or triangle tarpaulin), is a simple kind of partial [[tent]] designed to provide temporary [[Shelter (building)|shelter]] and concealment when combined with one or more sections. Two sheets of canvas or a similar material (the halves) are fastened together with snaps, straps or buttons to form a larger surface. The shelter-half is then erected using poles, ropes, pegs, and whatever tools are on hand, forming an inverted V structure.<ref>[http://mobile.outdoorhistory.com/xmlui/bitstream/handle/123456789/5176/FM15-85CareAndUseIndividualClothingEquipment1985.pdf Care And Use of Individual Clothing and Equipment] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141031184238/http://mobile.outdoorhistory.com/xmlui/bitstream/handle/123456789/5176/FM15-85CareAndUseIndividualClothingEquipment1985.pdf |date=2014-10-31 }}, US Army File Manual FM15-85, 1985, pp. 3-4ff</ref> Small tents like these are often called '''pup tents'''" in [[American English]].
Shelter halves are a mainstay of most armies, and are known from the mid 19th century.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tent, Shelter Half (Pup Tent)|url=http://olive-drab.com/od_soldiers_gear_shelter_half.php|publisher=Olive-Drab|accessdate=3 October 2012}}</ref> Often, each soldier carries one shelter-half and half the poles, etc., and they pair off to erect a two-man tent. The size and shape of each half shelter piece may vary from army to army, but are typically rectangular, triangular or [[Rhombus|lozenge]] shaped. When time and space allow, some forms of half-shelters can be combined into a larger, more complex tent.<ref>{{cite web|title=Interesting gear: The Zeltbahn shelter-quarter|url=http://oblio13.blogspot.no/2008/09/interesting-gear-zeltbahn-shelter.html|work=Philosophizing with a Hammer}}</ref>
Shelter-halves are usually designed to serve double duty as [[ponchos]] against the rain, or for the concealment of [[snipers]]. While the fabric is often simple [[olive drab]], several nations use camouflaged fabric. The first printed camouflage for soldiers were the Italian ''[[Telo mimetico]]'' introduced in 1929 for their half-shelters.<ref>{{cite web|last=Turner|first=B.|title=Italian three-colour camouflage (2nd pattern)|url=http://www.kamouflage.net/camouflage/00295.php|publisher=Kamouflage.net|accessdate=3 October 2012}}</ref> The first camouflage uniforms were the Second World War German paratrooper smock, based on their M1931 [[Splittermuster]] shelter-halves.<ref>{{cite book|last=Davis|first=Brian L.|title=German Army uniforms and insignia : 1933 - 1945|year=1998|publisher=Brockhampton Press|location=London|isbn=978-1-86019-869-4}}</ref> Russian Army has used ''Plasch-palatkas'' (literally "cape-tents", designed to be used as both a part of a larger tent cover, or an individual weatherproof cape) since 1894,<ref name=Ulianov>{{cite book|last=Ulianov|first=I.|title=History of Russian Army: Regular Infantry 1885-1918|year=1998|publisher=AST|location=Moscow|isbn=5-15-000508-8}}</ref> and the modern version, virtually unchanged since, was introduced in 1936,<ref name=Burdin>Col. S.Burdin, "The Rear and Supplies of the [[Red Army]]" #9, 1942, in Russian</ref> with the camo version being available since 1942.<ref name=Burdin /> To add some confusion, the ordinary waterproofed cape with a similar name (plasch-nakidka, "cape-overcoat") was issued at the same time, but these weren't intended to combine with each other.<ref name=Ulianov />
<gallery> File:Camp Crane Pup Tents.jpg|Camp Crane pup tents File:Dutch army tent 1955.jpg|Dutch Army pup tent from 1955 File:PolnischesMilitaerzelt Bild10 ZweiZeltbahnenOberseite-I 17Aug2013 (9543480062).jpg|Two Polish Army shelter halves fastened together File:PolnischesMilitaerzelt Bild07 ZeltAufgebautEingang-I 17Aug2013 (9543481422).jpg|Polish Army tent erected Pfadfinderstamm Ägypten - Wanderung bei St. Bartholomä, Eiskapelle, 1993.png|German [[Boy Scouts]] with M1931 [[Splittermuster]] shelter-halves in 1993 File:Плащ-палатка,_МО_РФ,_лежит_на_земле.JPG|Russian ''plasch-palatka'' spread over ground </gallery>
==See also== *[[Bivouac shelter]] *[[Lean-to]] *[[Swag (bedroll)]]
